urn:contentItem:4P3V-PTY0-TXN5-S34Y-00000-00Letters2007-03-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:58ZLexisNexisBUSINESSOpinion & AnalysisPg. 14Letters

Forest stewards neglect duty

WELL may Victoria's Emergency Services Commissioner Bruce Esplin blame global warming and anything else that gets in his way when rationalising the recent fires. The greatest cause for the hyper fires was the Government neglect of the public's land over at least the past 20 years.

All conservation ministers of all political parties since 1982 have deliberately neglected their stewardship of the public's land.

From 1944 to 1984 the forest fire outbreaks were attended to and extinguished within, mainly, hours rather than weeks.

The old-timers knew the value of fuel reduction burning and didn't let a huge rule book get in their way.

Mr Esplin might learn a lot from those he scorns - as his treatment of the members of Forest Fire (Vic) Inc indicates he has no sense of history and is not interested in the cheap, effective ways of past foresters.

John Cribbes, Sale

Questions unanswered

DR FRASER, CSIRO chief research scientist (Business, 1/3), challenges my questioning (Business, 20/2) the conclusion that scientists agree it is 90 per cent certain that most of the global warming since 1950 is due to human activity.

He seemingly relies mainly on the International Panel on Climate Change's use of peer-reviewed scientific papers and its 1300-year temperature reconstructions showing that temperature levels of the past 50 years are unusual.

He also denies that the hockey stick temperature reconstruction of the past 1000 years is invalid.

Dr Fraser's dismissal of the Fraser Institute and World Economics reports as obscure unjustifiably overlooks those reports' composition by prominent scientific and economic analysts, a process itself effectively constituting a peer review.

No meaningful scientific consensus exists when growing numbers of qualified analysts are rejecting the certainty thesis.

As to hockey sticks, Professor Wegman's US Congress report indicates serious statistical errors.

Des Moore, Director, Institute for Private Enterprise, South Yarra

urn:contentItem:5MH6-HJX1-JD34-V2CS-00000-00'Bush doof' shut down2016-12-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:58ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 7'Bush doof' shut downShana Morgan

Most people would not have heard about the rave planned for about 500 people in the Buckland Valley forest earlier this month, but rangers certainly did.

They got word about the event early and arrived at the destination just as the organiser and two others were setting up portable toilets and other equipment.

Having no permit meant the rave was shut down by police and Forest Fire Management Victoria before it started.

FFMV senior forest investigator Samantha Moore said 500 people had had committed to going and 1500 said they were "interested" in the event on Facebook.

"First and foremost, it's about safety â€¦ consideration is not given to important controls such as first aid requirements, dangerous trees, toilet and litter facilities, accessibility for emergency services in the event of an incident or bushfire, or the impact that the events have on the environment," she said.

"They are for-profit parties, they're making money from it."

Authorised festivals are required to meet guidelines for requirements such as medical backup, toilets and crowd control.

In this case, the Buckland Valley rave organiser warned a nearby camper he might want to move because a party was going to start.

"The forest is there for everybody to use," Ms Moore said. "It has been a significant problem in the past, not just in Buckland Valley, but around Victoria."

DELWP used its own Facebook page to contact the Buckland Valley event organiser and it was able to be cancelled before revellers took over the forest.

Ms Moore said it was usually a combination of organisers not having knowledge of the required permits and believing they could get away with it which led to trouble.

DELWP has warned any illegal raves planned in the bush for New Year parties would not be tolerated.

Charges for conducting an activity for profit on Crown land can be heard in court and be dealt with by fines between $3109 for an individual and $15,546 for a company.

The worst-case scenario for an unauthorised rave occurred near Grafton in June when a 24-year-old man died in his car, 200 metres from where people were dancing.

NSW Police Detective Inspector Darren Jameson said rave organisers showed no regard for safety.

"They need to be shut down and stopped - evidence of their disregard shows how they failed to stop the event despite someone dying in front of them," he said.

urn:contentItem:5H0S-JH41-JD3N-54GJ-00000-00RIDE KIDMAN TRAIL2015-09-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:58ZLexisNexisLIFESTYLEPg. 39RIDE KIDMAN TRAIL

easy 225KM 4-5 days

THE 255KM KIDMAN TRAIL is a long distance multi-use trail. Beginning in Willunga, it runs north along quiet roads, state forest fire trails, farm access tracks and unmade road reserves to finish at Kapunda. To safely plan and undertake a ride on the Kidman Trail (kidmantrail. org.au), it's essential to have the official map from Bicycle SA (8168 9999, bikesa. asn.au) and ForestrySA campsites will need to be booked in advance (forestry. sa.gov.au). Riding time is 5-7 days to complete (or plan half or full-day rides).

Willunga to Echunga Easy, nearly flat cycling through the townships of McLaren Vale and McLaren Flat. The trail then turns up the escarpment and heads towards Kuitpo Forest, where there's an extensive range of marked trails. It then links forest reserves through to Echunga.

ECHUNGA TO NAIRNE From Echunga, travel along Hack Ranges and enjoy expansive views towards Lower Lakes on one side and pocket-sized mixed farming on the other. Stop in historic Macclesfield before heading across the hills, through unmade road reserves and under the freeway to Nairne.

NAIRNE TO MOUNT CRAWFORD This section utilises country roads and fire tracks, and travels through landscapes made famous in the television series Rain Shadow... low stone walls, granite outcrops, sheoak trees, kangaroos, stony creeks. Finish this section through the Mount Crawford Forest; ensure you take a short diversion along a marked trail to the top of Mount Pleasant for a great view.

Mount Crawford to Stockwell A popular section with cyclists, this section features many undulating roads along ridgetops and between vineyards.Stockwell to Kapunda This section follows country roads and farm tracks, with many now having an attractive "single track" running adjacent to the main trail. Heavy clay soils make the last leg into Kapunda difficult after rain.

urn:contentItem:5NDK-3CF1-F0J6-J46Y-00000-00Memorial service2017-04-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:58ZLexisNexisNEWSMemorial service

A pleasing crowd gathered at the SA Volunteer Fire Fighters Memorial in Naracoorte on Saturday to honour the lives of eight fallen Forestry SA firefighters.

Distinguished guests and members of the public witnessed the unveiling of a plaque which paid tribute to the men who died in the Wandilo Forest Fire on April 5, 1958.

SA Volunteer Fire Fighters Museum chairman Rex Hall said it was a significant day for the families of the fallen and a very humbling experience.

"The feedback from those people was very emotional," Mr Hall said. "It affected some of them greater because they haven't had an opportunity I don't think to pay their respects for a number of years or ever."

Mr Hall said there was an overwhelming response when invitations were sent to politicians, dignitaries and community members.

"There was in excess of 200 (people) which was a little better than we expected so it was excellent."

Mr Hall said relatives and friends of deceased fire fighters travelled from across the state to be present on Saturday.

Forestry SA chief executive Jerome Coleman believes the plaque was a fitting tribute and said it was "heartening" to see a big turnout.

"Forestry SA are very honoured to be asked to add the eight names of the people who died in 1958," Mr Coleman said.

"It was a lovely service and I appreciate everyone who was involved."

Mr Coleman feels the new monument serves as a "small token and a good reminder" of the tragic event.

"This is another opportunity to plant this in everyone's memory," he said. "Hopefully we remember and think twice before we do things."

Mr Coleman said Forestry SA has been putting a big investment into equipment and training to prevent a similar events occurring.

"The message I'd like to put out there is that we are very serious about fire, we take our responsibility as a community and fire protection very seriously and we've learnt a lot from these losses," he said.

Both stakeholders strongly feel there is a unity across all emergency services bodies when dealing with serious matters.

"When it comes to big things like fire the only way you can do it is a team and that's very important," Mr Coleman said.

"All the emergency services are like a big family," Mr Hall said.

The volunteer fire fighters museum chair believes laying the plaque ties in well with the site's overall purpose.

"Our heritage is recognising volunteers who've given their lives so it all fits together with the history of the fire service."

urn:contentItem:49N9-VWS0-01S8-D0VY-00000-00<published>1992-03-02T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:40:58Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>FOREST FIRE TOO HOT THAT'S FINAL</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">A SUPERB header from midfielder Roy Keane 10 minutes into extra time today booked Brian Clough's Nottingham Forest another Wembley Cup final appearance.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Forest beat Tottenham 2-1 - 3-2 on aggregate to reach the English League Cup Final and exact substantial revenge for its FA Cup final defeat by the London Club Last May.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Forest and long-serving manager Clough now bid for a record fifth League Cup win. Their opponent will be Manchester United or second division Middlesbrough, who start their two-leg semi-final tie on Wednesday.</p><p>It will be Forest's sixth League Cup Final appearance, a record in the 31-year-old competition they now share with Liverpool.</p><p> Sunday's match was delayed an hour after a small bomb planted by the IRA was spotted and defused on railway tracks near the Totenham ground. Police also searched the Stadium.</p><p> Lee Glover shot Forest into an 11th minute lead but Spurs equalised through Gary Lineker four minutes later. Neither side could break the deadlock on a gluepot pitch in the pouring rain.</p><p> The match went to extra time and Keane's powerful header from a corner on the right proved decisive.FRENCH soccer international Eric Cantona scored his first goal for Leeds United, the opener in its 2-0 win against Luton yesterday, by default.</p><p> On a day marred by pitch invasions at Birmingham and West Ham, Cantona, at least, had something to take pleasure from.</p><p> Leeds manager Howard Wilkinson said: "If it hadn't been for injuries, Eric would have spent more time on the bench than he has since joining us." Wilkinson, who brought Cantona on for the first time as a substitute in a rare 2-0 defeat at Oldham three weeks ago, said: "He has a lot to offer, but we have a communication problem while he learns the language.</p><p> "We're in the trenches and by the time you shout 'duck', he's dead." Wilkinson found himself having to send Cantona on as a substitute after half an hour for his home debut at Elland Rd when England defender Tony Dorigo was injured.</p><p> Half an hour later the Frenchman, who joined Leeds on loan at the beginning of the month, tapped home the opening goal after midfielder Gary McAllister had split the Luton defence.</p><p> Five minutes from time Cantona, Jean-Pierre Papin's strike partner in France's European championship side, laid on the second goal for Lee Chapman.</p><p> Cantona, determined to earn a $1.75 millon transfer to Leeds from his French club Nimes, said through an interpreter: "I find English football very fast and hard, but I'm enjoying it." Leeds's victory left it just two points behind leader Manchester United, which dropped two in a 0-0 draw at Coventry.</p><p> It was United's sixth draw in the past eight games, but manager Alex Ferguson said: "At the end of the day it's not a terrible result for us.</p><p> "We could have done with a bit more cutting edge in the last third of the field. And it was disappointing that Ryan Giggs got to the dead ball line a few times without producing anything more." Teenage Welsh star Giggs was served a golden chance by Paul Ince but missed an open goal.</p><p> The title race in Scotland looks all but won after champions Rangers opened a seven-point lead over second-placed Hearts with a 5-0 win at home against Airdrie.</p><p> Former England striker Mark Hateley bagged a hat-trick to take his totaler Englishman, Paul Rideout, who was bought as cover and scored his first goal for Rangers.</p><p> Arch Glasgow rivals Celtic lent a hand by winning 2-1 at Hearts, a pair of headed goals by Gerry Creaney also taking his season's tally to 17.</p><p> - REUTER</p><p> END OF STORY</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content><nitf:body.end><graphic><nitf:media><caption><p>He's back . . . former West Ham favorite Tony Cottee (right) fires ina shot for Everton in the match against his old club at Upton Park. Evertonwon 2-0. He's back . . . French goal ace Eric Cantona (right) celebratesscoring for Leeds United against Luton.</p></caption></nitf:media></graphic></nitf:body.end></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:5RJ1-KWD1-F0J6-J1W3-00000-00Wednesday, February 72018-02-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:58ZLexisNexisGREEN GUIDEPg. 12Wednesday, February 7

pay What on Earth?

Discovery, 9.30am

There's an unpleasant mystery-mongering vibe to this series about some of the remarkable sights photographed by satellites in recent years. Which is a pity, because it would have been far more interesting if they'd just played it straight. There's no need for the initial pretence that the forest fire that covered much of Siberia in smoke in 2016 might have been started by some top-secret Russian weather weapon. Nor to pretend that the wreck of a drug smuggler's plane visible in shallow water off the Bahamian island used by Pablo Escobar's pal Carlos Lehder is anything but that. Indeed, proper disclosure would have made clear that the plane is no startling discovery and is in fact a well-known snorkelling site popular with tourists. Sheesh! BN

movie Savages (2012)

Thriller Movies (pay TV), 8.30pm

Chon (Taylor Kitsch), Ben (Aaron Taylor-Johnson) and the film's narrator, Ophelia (Blake Lively), are beautiful Californian kids - respectively a former Navy SEAL, gifted botanist, and blonde dream girl sexually committed to both young men - who together live off the proceeds of a high-end hydroponic marijuana operation in this glib Oliver Stone crime drama. The trio's sweet life is interrupted by a brutal Mexican narcotics cartel, commanded by the vengeful widow Elena (Salma Hayek) and marshalled by the bloodthirsty Lado (Benicio Del Toro), who live out murderous fantasies south of the border. When a takeover becomes a kidnapping, the plot still resembles Don Winslow's novel, but the lean, calibrated prose is replaced by Stone's visual excess, rife with lurid preening but bereft of insight. The result is bloody and deluded, self-satisfied and demeaning.CM

Squinters

ABC, 9pm

The twice-daily crawl through peak-hour traffic becomes a backdrop for life's larger dramas in Squinters. Each 20-minute episode of this comedy series is divided in two: the trip to work and the journey home, with the working day condensed into a neat time-lapse segment in between. The vehicles of the characters become tiny theatres, and the stories we watch through their windscreens are compelling, poignant and hilarious, thanks to sharp writing and terrific performances from the ensemble cast. Our characters are all employees of consumer goods dispatch centre Kosciusko (the title refers to their trip facing the sun as they head east from Sydney's western suburbs). The confined setting of the cars keeps the focus on the characters, their developing relationships and the wonderfully restrained dialogue. It's clever, unusual and enormously enjoyable television. LS

Living Black: Kevin Rudd

NITV, 9pm

How much you enjoy this tete-a-tete between Kevin Rudd and Living Black presenter Karla Grant probably depends on how you feel about Rudd. The interview marks the 10th anniversary of Rudd's apology to Indigenous Australians - an achievement of which he is rightly proud. The interview is wide-ranging - we cover his childhood, his ideas about Indigenous policy and, of course, his power struggle with Julia Gillard. It's a cosy chat rather than an interrogation so Rudd's version of events goes unchallenged and it's clear he still sees himself as a wronged hero. LS

urn:contentItem:5NGV-9YS1-F0J6-J2Y7-00000-00Memorial service2017-04-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:58ZLexisNexisMemorial service

A pleasing crowd gathered at the SA Volunteer Fire Fighters Memorial in Naracoorte on Saturday to honour the lives of eight fallen Forestry SA fire fighters.

Distinguished guests and members of the public witnessed the unveiling of a plaque which paid tribute to the men who died in the Wandilo Forest Fire on April 5, 1958.

SA Volunteer Fire Fighters Museum chairman Rex Hall said it was a significant day for the families of the fallen and a very humbling experience.

"The feedback from those people was very emotional," Mr Hall said. "It affected some of them greater because they haven't had an opportunity I don't think to pay their respects for a number of years or ever."

Mr Hall said there was an overwhelming response when invitations were sent to politicians, dignitaries and community members.

"There was in excess of 200 (people) which was a little better than we expected so it was excellent."

Mr Hall said relatives and friends of deceased fire fighters travelled from across the state to be present on Saturday.

Forestry SA chief executive Jerome Coleman believes the plaque was a fitting tribute and said it was "heartening" to see a big turnout.

"Forestry SA are very honoured to be asked to add the eight names of the people who died in 1958," Mr Coleman said.

"It was a lovely service and I appreciate everyone who was involved."

Mr Coleman feels the new monument serves as a "small token and a good reminder" of the tragic event.

"This is another opportunity to plant this in everyone's memory," he said. "Hopefully we remember and think twice before we do things."

Mr Coleman said Forestry SA has been putting a big investment into equipment and training to prevent a similar events occurring.

"The message I'd like to put out there is that we are very serious about fire, we take our responsibility as a community and fire protection very seriously and we've learnt a lot from these losses," he said.

Both stakeholders strongly feel there is a unity across all emergency services bodies when dealing with serious matters.

"When it comes to big things like fire the only way you can do it is a team and that's very important," Mr Coleman said.

"All the emergency services are like a big family," Mr Hall said.

The volunteer fire fighters museum chair believes laying the plaque ties in well with the site's overall purpose.

"Our heritage is recognising volunteers who've given their lives so it all fits together with the history of the fire service."

urn:contentItem:5KFS-TGX1-JD67-11WF-00000-00Shielded from falling trees2016-08-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:58ZLexisNexisNEWSShielded from falling treesShana Morgan

Protection from falling trees was on the forefront of minds when Forest Fire Management Victoria created its new G-wagon vehicles.

Three years ago, two Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning firefighters were killed at Harrietville in treacherous conditions when an Alpine ash tree fell on their slip-on vehicle.

The department has now launched four-wheel-drive ultra-light tankers, which featured a 'falling object protection structure' above the cabin to better protect fire crews in from trees and branches in hazardous areas.

Upper Murray district manager Aaron Kennedy said the vehicles were one part of the safety response to the Harrietville tragedy.

'It definitely influenced it, an outcome of Harrietville was about how we could improve protection for our staff,' he said.

'It's going to reduce the impact from a falling tree.'

The deaths of Steven Kadar and Katie Peters were subject to a coronial inquest last year.

DELWP also implemented guidelines to ensure firefighters were no longer sent into dangerous situations.

The 30 new Mercedes Benz G-wagon tankers are being distributed across the region, including five each at Tallangatta, Mitta and Corryong.

The tankers have a 630-litre water capacity, more than the 400L capacity of older vehicles, an electronic rewind, so firefighters do not have to pull in hose reels manually, and storage areas at a more accessible height.

'The vehicle itself is more ergonomic, more self-sufficient,' Mr Kennedy said.

'For the past three years they've been through the designing phase and have engaged with our staff and industry experts to try and come up with the best, most practical vehicle for firefighting, but also for safety.'

The G-wagon vehicles will be immediately put to use this summer for planned burning and emergency fire response, but have also been tested in the snow of Rubicon Valley.

DELWP forest and fire operations Hume regional manager Shaun Lawlor said the allocation of more than 300 vehicles across Victoria was based on the hazardous tree risk in each location.

'Victoria is the first state in Australia to have implemented this level of falling object protection in its firefighting vehicles,' he said.

'DELWP firefighters work in some of Victoria's toughest and most remote forest terrain.'

urn:contentItem:5XT6-T8D1-F0J6-J3CH-00000-00Watch and act, advice messages issued as bushfires burn out of control2019-12-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:58ZLexisNexisWatch and act, advice messages issued as bushfires burn out of controlKyra Gillespie, Jessica Howard

Update, Sunday 11.30am: Fires are still burning across the south-west, with at least eight of them being out-of-control.

A CFA spokesman said brigades have had "a number of busy days, starting with the total fire ban on Friday when we had the Henty fire."

"We then had the subsequent lightening strikes that came through the district which led to a number of fires across the region yesterday," he said.

"A number of those are still not yet under control. Lightening has been the biggest issue. The fires are being managed out of the Heywood Incident Control Centre."

There is a bushfire 17 kilometres west of Heywood, near Wrights Swamp Road in the Cobboboonee, and a smaller fire two kilometres south-west of Lyons that are not yet under control.

Firefighters have managed to halt the spread of these two fires.

The Department of Environment, Land, Water & Planning issued the following advice message for Drumborg, Greenwals and Lyons at 5.40am on Sunday:

"There is currently no threat to communities, but you should continue to stay informed and monitor conditions.

"Smoke may be visible from nearby roads and communities. Numerous Forest tracks in the Cobboboonee Forest are closed."

Advice messages have also been issued for Breakaway Creek, Lake Condah, Hotspur, Bahgallah, Casterton, Digby, Killara, Mocamboro and Sandford.

Update, Saturday 5pm: ALMOST every south-west fire brigade has been deployed as several bushfires burn across the district.

The fires were started by a lightning storm on Friday night and have been exacerbated by wind conditions on Saturday, CFA public information officer Sharon Mifsud said.

"They've all started from the lightning that came through last night, there was a big band of lightning and with the wind picking up today that's sparked some of them up," she said.

"We've got four messages out for the fires at the moment. There's lots of crews out there at the moment and there's a fair bit of smoke in the area so there could be other fires in the landscapes as well.

"If people do see something that's not matching up with the VicEmergency app they can still call triple zero."

READ MORE: Firefighters battle 33 new fires after cool change brings lightning

No lives or properties have been reported lost.

Ms Mifsud said people should update their fire management plans.

"It's a good reminder for people to review their survival plans," she said.

"We have just about all our brigades out there at the moment, we've only held a couple back in case there's any new incidents.

"Forest fire management crews are out there as well.

"It's not like the fire is in one spot, they're all over the place which adds to the complexities."

CFA issued an advice message for Bessiebelle, Breakaway Creek, Homerton, Lake Condah and Macarthur at 3:44pm on Saturday:

"There is a bushfire at Millard Track, Lake Condah that is not yet under control.

"The bushfire is travelling from Lake Condah in a northerly direction towards Budj Bim (Mount Eccles).

"There is currently no threat to you, but you should plan for what you will do if the situation changes."

The next update is expected by 21/12/2019 07.50 pm or as the situation changes.

An advice message was also put in place at 1:15pm on Saturday for Bahgallah, Casterton, Dartmoor, Digby, Henty, Killara, Merino, Mocamboro and Sandford for two out of control bushfires.

As of 4.53pm, three vehicles were responding to a 111-hectare bushfire at Digby-Strathdownie Road Killara not yet under control.

The bushfire was travelling from Digby-Strathdownie Road in a northerly direction towards Range Road.

As of 1.49pm, 29 vehicles responded to a small bushfire nearby.

There is currently no threat to communities.

As of 4.24pm there was an out of control bushfire 19 kilometres east of Dartmoor travelling from The Boulevard near Crawford River in a northerly direction towards Digby.

There is currently no threat to communities.

Earlier, 3pm: A watch and act message has been issued for residents in and around the Heywood area.

Drumborg, Greenwald, Heywood, Hotspur, Lyons, Milltown, Mount Richmond and West Sinclair have been warned of an out of control bushfire at Wrights Swamp Road, Cobboboonee National Park.

The bushfire is travelling from Wrights Swamp Road in a northerly direction towards Drumborg.

A CFA spokeswoman said the fire was near the Jackass Fern Gully and Fitzroy picnic and camping areas.

Forest Management Victoria issued the following warning at 2:47pm:

"Don't wait, leaving now is the safest option - conditions may change and get worse very quickly. Emergency Services may not be able to help you if you decide to stay."

What you should do:

Monitor changes to the situation. Increased wind speed, change in wind direction, smoke or poor visibility can indicate the situation is changing. If you are away from home, do not return. If the situation changes or you feel unsafe you should leave:

Take your pets, medications, mobile phone and charger. Travel to the home of family or friends that are away from the warning area or to Heywood. Emergency Services may not be able to help you if you decide to stay.

Impacts in your area:

Bushfires can spread quickly and are extremely dangerous. Bushfires can start spot fires and embers large distances ahead of the main fire. Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au/) or call 13 11 70 for road closures. The next update is expected by 21/12/2019 06:50 pm or as the situation changes.

urn:contentItem:5SPX-P2M1-JD34-V250-00000-00Tribute complete: SAVFFM Memorial is finished2018-07-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:58ZLexisNexisTribute complete: SAVFFM Memorial is finishedAmy Maynard

The memorial section of the South Australian Volunteer Fire Fighters Museum (SAVFFM) has officially been completed.

On Tuesday morning invited guests came for a tour of what has been finished so far, and to hear what the next stage is for the SAVFFM.

From Federal Parliament, guests included Member for Barker Tony Pasin, and Assistant Minister to the Deputy Prime Minister, Keith Pitt. Mr Pitt is from Queensland, and during his presentation chairman Rex Hall joked that the weather was a little bit nicer where he was from.

Mr Pasin has frequently observed the construction of the SAVFFM, and even spoke about the work of its volunteers in Parliament last week.

"This dedicated group based in Naracoorte, my electorate, who are seeking to establish a museum complex, have done a stellar job over many years," he said.

"From humble beginnings, because of lots of hard work, fundraising and donations from CFS brigades in the region, we now have a memorial to commemorate those who lost their lives."

Member for MacKillop Nick McBride was in Parliament, so staffer Jenny Schilling was his representative.

Local council representatives were Mayor Erika Vickery, CEO Trevor Smart, and Director of Operations Steve Bourne.

From the CFS, there was Region Five Commander John Probert, Colin Chomel of the Mount Lofty CFS, and Vince Monterosa, of the Stirling CFS.

From industry there was David Wheaton (Regional Development), David Bull (Bull Bros) and Chris Gibson (Forestry SA).

Mr Hall said he was appreciative of the amount of construction work Bull Bros had done for the SAVFFM, noting that around 50 per cent of the work had been completed by the Naracoorte-based company.

Forestry SA has been given a flag and a plaque at the memorial site, in memory of the Woods and Forests Department firefighters who lost their lives during the Wandilo forest fire in 1958.

Mr Hall also thanked the volunteers for all of their hard work, and acknowledged the work of those who were absent.

In particular, the business plan for the museum would not have been completed without Frank Brennan and Robin Holmes. The business plan took 12 months to complete.

Ian Benjamin drew the plans, which were viewed later that morning in the Cartwright Pavilion.

Plans for the Museum and Memorial began approximately 14 years ago by what was then known as the Heritage Committee.

The site of the Museum and Memorial was chosen after the committee carefully looked at various options. It is placed at Kingston Avenue in order to be a tourist attraction - close to the highway.

Mr Hall and the rest of the volunteers have been busy collecting memorabilia for the Museum, which is about to be constructed.

According to Mr Hall, the Museum already has enough memorabilia to fill two buildings.

"It's not just going to be a museum - it's going to be a learning hub for future generations," Mr Hall said.

After looking at the Memorial, the guests were invited to look at the museum memorabilia in the Cartwright Pavilion. The memorabilia includes vintage firetrucks, photos, and antique equipment.

Mr Chomel pointed out a firetruck that had been imported from England, which had special seating so firefighters could quickly get their gear on whilst still in the truck.

There was also a firetruck from Tea Tree Gully that had been converted from an old army vehicle.

"You could do 70kmph and not even spill a cup of coffee in that truck," Mr Chomel explained.

After browsing the exhibits, guests were invited to partake in a morning tea.

urn:contentItem:5RJW-JV11-F0J6-J1CF-00000-00pay What on Earth?Discovery, 9...2018-02-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:58ZLexisNexisTHE GUIDEPg. 6pay What on Earth?Discovery, 9...

pay What on Earth?

Discovery, 9.30am

There's an unpleasant mystery-mongering vibe to this series about some of the remarkable sights photographed by satellites in recent years. Which is a pity, because it would have been far more interesting if they'd just played it straight. There's no need for the initial pretence that the forest fire that covered much of Siberia in smoke in 2016 might have been started by some top-secret Russian weather weapon. Nor to pretend that the wreck of a drug smuggler's plane visible in shallow water off the Bahamian island used by Pablo Escobar's pal Carlos Lehder is anything but that. Indeed, proper disclosure would have made clear that the plane is no startling discovery and is in fact a well-known snorkelling site popular with tourists. Sheesh! BN

movie Savages (2012)

Thriller Movies (pay TV), 8.30pm

Chon (Taylor Kitsch), Ben (Aaron Taylor-Johnson) and the film's narrator, Ophelia (Blake Lively), are beautiful Californian kids - respectively a former Navy SEAL, gifted botanist, and blonde dream girl sexually committed to both young men - who together live off the proceeds of a high-end hydroponic marijuana operation in this glib Oliver Stone crime drama. The trio's sweet life is interrupted by a brutal Mexican narcotics cartel, commanded by the vengeful widow Elena (Salma Hayek) and marshalled by the bloodthirsty Lado (Benicio Del Toro), who live out murderous fantasies south of the border. When a takeover becomes a kidnapping, the plot still resembles Don Winslow's novel, but the lean, calibrated prose is replaced by Stone's visual excess, rife with lurid preening but bereft of insight. The result is bloody and deluded, self-satisfied and demeaning.CM

Squinters

ABC, 9pm

The twice-daily crawl through peak-hour traffic becomes a backdrop for life's larger dramas in Squinters. Each 20-minute episode of this comedy series is divided in two: the trip to work and the journey home, with the working day condensed into a neat time-lapse segment in between. The vehicles of the characters become tiny theatres, and the stories we watch through their windscreens are compelling, poignant and hilarious, thanks to sharp writing and terrific performances from the ensemble cast. Our characters are all employees of consumer goods dispatch centre Kosciusko (the title refers to their trip facing the sun as they head east from Sydney's western suburbs). The confined setting of the cars keeps the focus on the characters, their developing relationships and the wonderfully restrained dialogue. It's clever, unusual and enormously enjoyable television. LS

Living Black: Kevin Rudd

NITV, 9pm

How much you enjoy this tete-a-tete between Kevin Rudd and Living Black presenter Karla Grant probably depends on how you feel about Rudd. The interview marks the 10th anniversary of Rudd's apology to Indigenous Australians - an achievement of which he is rightly proud. The interview is wide-ranging - we cover his childhood, his ideas about Indigenous policy and, of course, his power struggle with Julia Gillard. It's a cosy chat rather than an interrogation so Rudd's version of events goes unchallenged and it's clear he still sees himself as a wronged hero. LS

There is currently no threat to communities.

Earlier, 3pm: A watch and act message has been issued for residents in and around the Heywood area.

Drumborg, Greenwald, Heywood, Hotspur, Lyons, Milltown, Mount Richmond and West Sinclair have been warned of an out of control bushfire at Wrights Swamp Road, Cobboboonee National Park.

The bushfire is travelling from Wrights Swamp Road in a northerly direction towards Drumborg.

A CFA spokeswoman said the fire was near the Jackass Fern Gully and Fitzroy picnic and camping areas.

Forest Management Victoria issued the following warning at 2:47pm:

"Don't wait, leaving now is the safest option - conditions may change and get worse very quickly. Emergency Services may not be able to help you if you decide to stay."

What you should do:

Monitor changes to the situation. Increased wind speed, change in wind direction, smoke or poor visibility can indicate the situation is changing. If you are away from home, do not return. If the situation changes or you feel unsafe you should leave:

Take your pets, medications, mobile phone and charger. Travel to the home of family or friends that are away from the warning area or to Heywood. Emergency Services may not be able to help you if you decide to stay.

Impacts in your area:

Bushfires can spread quickly and are extremely dangerous. Bushfires can start spot fires and embers large distances ahead of the main fire. Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au/) or call 13 11 70 for road closures. The next update is expected by 21/12/2019 06:50 pm or as the situation changes.

Have you signed up to The Standard's daily newsletter and breaking news emails? You can register below and make sure you are up to date with everything that's happening in the south-west.

urn:contentItem:5XSS-VY51-JD34-V1D9-00000-00Ballarat's team effort2019-12-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:58ZLexisNexisBallarat's team effort

PREPARING for an emergency situation on a high fire danger day is a multi-agency effort.

On a day with a real potential for serious fires to break out across the region and a severe fire danger rating, such as Friday when the temperature exceeded 40 degrees in the Ballarat region, staff from a number of agencies including Forest Fire Management Victoria, the Country Fire Authority, police and representatives from local government agencies gather at the Incident Control Centre, located in a quiet street in Sebastopol.

The ICC - which covers the area from Blackwood to Clunes, across to Mt Cole and over to Dereel - is the central point from which the appointed members of the incident management team provide direction to the response in the event of an emergency situation. At peak capacity more than 130 people can be present.

Three Incident Control Centres (ICC) operated in the Grampians region on Friday - at Ballarat, Ararat and Horsham - under the Australasian Inter-Service Incident Management System. By 9am, people from all manner of agencies had started to flood into the building to be briefed for the day ahead, donning coloured vests outlining their titles, looking at maps and making phone calls.

The expertise and preparedness for the possibility of a major event was clear in a briefing of all agencies at 10am, in which the weather forecast and other potential risks and what resources would be available should an event unfold were communicated.

A sombre feeling spread across the room when the two volunteer firefighters who died in the line of duty in New South Wales the night before were mentioned - a poignant reminder of the risks associated with firefighting.

By mid-morning pagers started to beep as the first fire of the day broke out near Haddon and people around the centre jumped to attention.

WEATHER WORRIES

Planning officer Peter Livitsanis had prepared a presentation on the day's weather forecast. He said the extreme dry heat coupled with wind was a concern throughout the day, with the heat expected to peak late around 2pm and little relief into the night.

While immediately around Ballarat itself was not so much of a worry, it was to the east towards Bacchus Marsh and to the west towards Beaufort and Ararat where real concern was focused.

Mr Livitsanis said while the Ballarat region was still green several weeks ago, the degree of grass curing following several days of hot weather was one worry for the teams. Another was a trough expected to travel through late on Friday evening that was expected to bring dry lightning strikes - posing a significant fire risk.

He said this was a particular concern as it would be fanned by a wind change at 11pm, meaning if a large fire broke out, it would continue overnight as no rain was forecast.

PREPARATION

Incident Controller, Deputy Chief Fire Officer Jon Rofe of FFMV, said the firefighting effort was a multi-faceted approach.

"The multi-agency effort is extremely important in what we do because we draw resources from all agencies and each agency has responsibility for different areas of the land," Mr Rofe said.

"It doesn't matter where the fire is in the landscape, we will all respond together. Each also agency brings complementary skills, which is hugely beneficial in what we are doing."

The incident management team is comprised of several teams including planning, operations, logistics and public information and is accentuated by an Emergency Management Team, comprised of Victoria Police, Ambulance Victoria and local government representatives.

The operations team manages the ground fire crew operations, which were at a heightened level of readiness on Friday. The FFMV and CFA firefighters work together on the ground, sharing skills and experience to fight fires. Their efforts are supported by water bombing aircraft.

"They slow the spread of the fire down, protect assets and support our on-ground firefighters with their operations," Mr Rofe said.

Other tools include having an air observation aircraft on standby as a means of fire detection or for aerial observation if an incident does occur, as well as the fire observers in the lookout towers around Ballarat.

FFMV Grampians is currently supporting the firefighting effort in Gippsland, meaning many staff are on the other side of the state. However, there is a local agreement with the CFA to supply additional resources if need be.

READY TO RESPOND

Deputy Incident Controller Commander Anthony Pearce said all CFA brigades were ready to respond to any incident which may occur, including the usual call-outs.

Keeping an eye on the weather conditions was critical, Commander Pearce said, so that a rapid dispatch of fire crews and aircraft could occur if a fire ignited.

Another crucial factor is disseminating warnings to the community as quickly as possible to allow residents to heed them and enact fire plans.

"Weather like this also increases the likelihood of a whole range of other fire calls - power lines dropping and air conditioners setting fire to buildings," he said. "We will see an increase in fire activity in general, not just increasing fire involving bush or grass."

IN THE AIR

Aircraft Officer Mark Lee was tasked with overseeing the deployment of aircraft.There are three aircraft stationed in Ballarat and all were prepared to launch from 10am: a light helicopter, a firebombing helicopter as well as a light fixed wing aircraft for use as an air observer platform, however there are other aircraft available to call on if need be, with 50 aircraft available across the state this fire season.

SUPPORT

Ballarat police's Senior Sergeant Peter McCormick is a Municipal Emergency Response Coordinator (MERC) for Ballarat.

His role, along with two other members representing Pyrenees and Moorabool, is to represent their local government areas and ensure effective command and control is in place and resources are distributed effectively.

Council representatives were also in attendance, including from the City of Ballarat, Hepburn Shire and Moorabool.

It is critical residents are vigilant and systems such as the Vic Emergency app to stay up to date with information.

-HAYLEY ELG

urn:contentItem:598M-JP21-JD3N-52BX-00000-00IN BRIEF2013-09-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:58ZLexisNexisWORLDPg. 16IN BRIEF

Yosemite blaze still spreading

A HUGE forest fire that broke out more than two weeks ago in California is 60 per cent under control, although it's still spreading, firefighters say. The Rim Fire in Yosemite National Forest is spreading at a slower pace than before, and the US Forest Service says it could be fully contained by September 20. About 100,000ha of forest have been destroyed by the blaze, which has caused an estimated $74 million of damage. About 5000 personnel and 20 helicopters are involved in the effort to stop the flames spreading. The fire on the borders of Yosemite National Park is now the fourth-biggest in US history, according to the Los Angeles Times.

Nokia calls it a day with sale

BELEAGUERED Finnish mobile phone maker Nokia will sell its mobile phone unit to US group Microsoft for $8.04 billion. Nokia will grant Microsoft a 10-year non-exclusive licence to its patents and will itself focus on network infrastructure and services, which it called ``the best path forward for Nokia and its shareholders'' in a joint news release from the two companies on Monday night. Microsoft chief executive Steve Ballmer says the deal will bring Nokia's capability and talent in hardware design, engineering, manufacturing, sales, marketing and distribution to Microsoft.

urn:contentItem:5RJW-HK31-JD34-V076-00000-00Wednesday, February 72018-02-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:58ZLexisNexisTHE GUIDEPg. 6Wednesday, February 7

pay What on Earth?

Discovery, 9.30am

There's an unpleasant mystery-mongering vibe to this series about some of the remarkable sights photographed by satellites in recent years. Which is a pity, because it would have been far more interesting if they'd just played it straight. There's no need for the initial pretence that the forest fire that covered much of Siberia in smoke in 2016 might have been started by some top-secret Russian weather weapon. Nor to pretend that the wreck of a drug smuggler's plane visible in shallow water off the Bahamian island used by Pablo Escobar's pal Carlos Lehder is anything but that. Indeed, proper disclosure would have made clear that the plane is no startling discovery and is in fact a well-known snorkelling site popular with tourists. Sheesh! BN

movie Savages (2012)

Thriller Movies (pay TV), 8.30pm

Chon (Taylor Kitsch), Ben (Aaron Taylor-Johnson) and the film's narrator, Ophelia (Blake Lively), are beautiful Californian kids - respectively a former Navy SEAL, gifted botanist, and blonde dream girl sexually committed to both young men - who together live off the proceeds of a high-end hydroponic marijuana operation in this glib Oliver Stone crime drama. The trio's sweet life is interrupted by a brutal Mexican narcotics cartel, commanded by the vengeful widow Elena (Salma Hayek) and marshalled by the bloodthirsty Lado (Benicio Del Toro), who live out murderous fantasies south of the border. When a takeover becomes a kidnapping, the plot still resembles Don Winslow's novel, but the lean, calibrated prose is replaced by Stone's visual excess, rife with lurid preening but bereft of insight. The result is bloody and deluded, self-satisfied and demeaning.CM

Squinters

ABC, 9pm

The twice-daily crawl through peak-hour traffic becomes a backdrop for life's larger dramas in Squinters. Each 20-minute episode of this comedy series is divided in two: the trip to work and the journey home, with the working day condensed into a neat time-lapse segment in between. The vehicles of the characters become tiny theatres, and the stories we watch through their windscreens are compelling, poignant and hilarious, thanks to sharp writing and terrific performances from the ensemble cast. Our characters are all employees of consumer goods dispatch centre Kosciusko (the title refers to their trip facing the sun as they head east from Sydney's western suburbs). The confined setting of the cars keeps the focus on the characters, their developing relationships and the wonderfully restrained dialogue. It's clever, unusual and enormously enjoyable television. LS

Living Black: Kevin Rudd

NITV, 9pm

How much you enjoy this tete-a-tete between Kevin Rudd and Living Black presenter Karla Grant probably depends on how you feel about Rudd. The interview marks the 10th anniversary of Rudd's apology to Indigenous Australians - an achievement of which he is rightly proud. The interview is wide-ranging - we cover his childhood, his ideas about Indigenous policy and, of course, his power struggle with Julia Gillard. It's a cosy chat rather than an interrogation so Rudd's version of events goes unchallenged and it's clear he still sees himself as a wronged hero. LS

urn:contentItem:5XSS-VY51-JD34-V1NF-00000-00Ballarat's team effort2019-12-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:58ZLexisNexisREAL ESTATEBallarat's team effort

PREPARING for an emergency situation on a high fire danger day is a multi-agency effort.

On a day with a real potential for serious fires to break out across the region and a severe fire danger rating, such as Friday when the temperature exceeded 40 degrees in the Ballarat region, staff from a number of agencies including Forest Fire Management Victoria, the Country Fire Authority, police and representatives from local government agencies gather at the Incident Control Centre, located in a quiet street in Sebastopol.

The ICC - which covers the area from Blackwood to Clunes, across to Mt Cole and over to Dereel - is the central point from which the appointed members of the incident management team provide direction to the response in the event of an emergency situation. At peak capacity more than 130 people can be present.

Three Incident Control Centres (ICC) operated in the Grampians region on Friday - at Ballarat, Ararat and Horsham - under the Australasian Inter-Service Incident Management System. By 9am, people from all manner of agencies had started to flood into the building to be briefed for the day ahead, donning coloured vests outlining their titles, looking at maps and making phone calls.

The expertise and preparedness for the possibility of a major event was clear in a briefing of all agencies at 10am, in which the weather forecast and other potential risks and what resources would be available should an event unfold were communicated.

A sombre feeling spread across the room when the two volunteer firefighters who died in the line of duty in New South Wales the night before were mentioned - a poignant reminder of the risks associated with firefighting.

By mid-morning pagers started to beep as the first fire of the day broke out near Haddon and people around the centre jumped to attention.

WEATHER WORRIES

Planning officer Peter Livitsanis had prepared a presentation on the day's weather forecast. He said the extreme dry heat coupled with wind was a concern throughout the day, with the heat expected to peak late around 2pm and little relief into the night.

While immediately around Ballarat itself was not so much of a worry, it was to the east towards Bacchus Marsh and to the west towards Beaufort and Ararat where real concern was focused.

Mr Livitsanis said while the Ballarat region was still green several weeks ago, the degree of grass curing following several days of hot weather was one worry for the teams. Another was a trough expected to travel through late on Friday evening that was expected to bring dry lightning strikes - posing a significant fire risk.

He said this was a particular concern as it would be fanned by a wind change at 11pm, meaning if a large fire broke out, it would continue overnight as no rain was forecast.

PREPARATION

Incident Controller, Deputy Chief Fire Officer Jon Rofe of FFMV, said the firefighting effort was a multi-faceted approach.

"The multi-agency effort is extremely important in what we do because we draw resources from all agencies and each agency has responsibility for different areas of the land," Mr Rofe said.

"It doesn't matter where the fire is in the landscape, we will all respond together. Each also agency brings complementary skills, which is hugely beneficial in what we are doing."

The incident management team is comprised of several teams including planning, operations, logistics and public information and is accentuated by an Emergency Management Team, comprised of Victoria Police, Ambulance Victoria and local government representatives.

The operations team manages the ground fire crew operations, which were at a heightened level of readiness on Friday. The FFMV and CFA firefighters work together on the ground, sharing skills and experience to fight fires. Their efforts are supported by water bombing aircraft.

"They slow the spread of the fire down, protect assets and support our on-ground firefighters with their operations," Mr Rofe said.

Other tools include having an air observation aircraft on standby as a means of fire detection or for aerial observation if an incident does occur, as well as the fire observers in the lookout towers around Ballarat.

FFMV Grampians is currently supporting the firefighting effort in Gippsland, meaning many staff are on the other side of the state. However, there is a local agreement with the CFA to supply additional resources if need be.

READY TO RESPOND

Deputy Incident Controller Commander Anthony Pearce said all CFA brigades were ready to respond to any incident which may occur, including the usual call-outs.

Keeping an eye on the weather conditions was critical, Commander Pearce said, so that a rapid dispatch of fire crews and aircraft could occur if a fire ignited.

Another crucial factor is disseminating warnings to the community as quickly as possible to allow residents to heed them and enact fire plans.

"Weather like this also increases the likelihood of a whole range of other fire calls - power lines dropping and air conditioners setting fire to buildings," he said. "We will see an increase in fire activity in general, not just increasing fire involving bush or grass."

IN THE AIR

Aircraft Officer Mark Lee was tasked with overseeing the deployment of aircraft.There are three aircraft stationed in Ballarat and all were prepared to launch from 10am: a light helicopter, a firebombing helicopter as well as a light fixed wing aircraft for use as an air observer platform, however there are other aircraft available to call on if need be, with 50 aircraft available across the state this fire season.

SUPPORT

Ballarat police's Senior Sergeant Peter McCormick is a Municipal Emergency Response Coordinator (MERC) for Ballarat.

His role, along with two other members representing Pyrenees and Moorabool, is to represent their local government areas and ensure effective command and control is in place and resources are distributed effectively.

Council representatives were also in attendance, including from the City of Ballarat, Hepburn Shire and Moorabool.

It is critical residents are vigilant and systems such as the Vic Emergency app to stay up to date with information.

-HAYLEY ELG

urn:contentItem:5XRY-25Y1-DXP7-1155-00000-00'What is needed to tackle the climate emergency, and who is responsible?'2019-12-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:58ZLexisNexis'What is needed to tackle the climate emergency, and who is responsible?'Patricia Thornley, Director, Energy and Bioproducts Research Institute, and Director, Supergen Bioenergy Hub, Aston University

What is the climate emergency, and whose climate crisis is it anyway?

What exactly are the nature of the changes needed to address the climate emergency, and who is responsible for making it happen?

An emergency is a situation where we need to act fast in order to prevent catastrophic consequences - like rushing to stop a child running in front of a bus, mobilising fire fighters to put out a forest fire, or intercepting a lorry smuggling explosives for a planned attack. Most would agree these are all examples of emergencies, but the timescales for action are different: seconds for the child, hours for the fire, and perhaps days or even months for the lorry. So while emergencies demand urgent, coordinated and effective responses, the exact timescale depends on the nature of emergency.

The weather can change from moment to moment, but climate is long term concept. It takes years for us even to collect enough data to notice that the climate is changing. Here, the emergency moves in years, not minutes. And the problem with things that change over many years is that there is always something else that appears to need more urgent attention.

For most of the last 30 years we have known that we need to do something about climate change, but other things have been perceived to be more important, and so it has been repeatedly pushed to the back of the queue. After all, the impact of climate change won't hit until 2050 or 2100, and that is just too far away to worry about - isn't it? In fact, most people on this planet will still be alive in 2050, when life for many of us is   projected to be looking pretty uncomfortable. And greenhouse gases linger in the atmosphere so long that our children will still be living with the environmental consequences of our carbon emissions of 2019 in 2100. So who should act?

It's easy to say that governments should do something - and perhaps they should. But the reality is that politicians generally do the things that they believe we want. So if we think it's the job of government to sort this mess out, we should be telling our politicians just that. We should be urging them to think long term not short term, and not to oppose measures like fuel duty escalators (a rising tax on fossil fuels to encourage alternatives) and   carbon taxes (a tax on burning fossil fuels as a way of pricing in the environmental damage they cause) just because they will hurt in the short term.

Radical measures required

It's going to take some pretty radical measures to wean us off our addiction to energy and the carbon emissions energy generation creates. Governments essentially have two main options: to reduce consumption by banning things, or by making them expensive so we use less. Of course, governments can also invest in new technology and new initiatives, but that is a longer term solution and doesn't really help address the need for urgent action now. If we want governments to do this, we must tell them so, and be prepared for the consequences.

I Need To Know is a series by The Conversation, which gives teenagers the chance to have their questions about the world answered by experts. Send your questions - along with your first name, age and the area where you live - to ineedtoknow@theconversation.com, or find out more ways to get in touch at the end of this article.

You could of course argue that governments don't generally run the most polluting industries such as power stations, cement works and factories. Industrialists are often pointed to as the real villains. But, again, they're really just making the furniture, clothing, toiletries and luxury goods that we demand, or that they think we'll want. It is consumption that drives markets, at home or abroad. If there was no demand for the colossal quantity of stuff that we consume every year, they would stop making it.

Some people argue that their consumption is small compared to others (the average Briton has a much lower carbon footprint than the average American, for example). But that becomes a playground game - "I'm not going to decarbonise if you're not going to decarbonise" - where we all want our share of the right to pollute. The reality is that our allowance of the cumulative emissions our planet, individually and as developed societies in the west, can withstand have already been used up. It is long past the time that we should create and consume less:   less meat, less petrol, less disposable nappies, toys, mobile phones, clothing, furniture -   less everything.

But what will we use in the future? That's where researchers, scientists and engineers come in. In thousands of universities worldwide there are scientists working on how to manufacture new materials, engineers devising technologies that do more with less, and social scientists making sure that the changes being proposed actually make sense in respect of people's lives in the real world. For example, ensuring low-carbon heating systems deliver the heating needed in older, draughty homes.

By bringing together the work of industry, policymakers, scientists and engineers, we can support the transition to a sustainable lifestyle where we consume less stuff, emit less carbon, and start becoming part of the solution - not the problem.

So, who needs to act? Everyone does. Governments, industry and us. We can be part of the solution by taking action in our own lives, by telling our politicians that we want them to act (even though we know it might make life hard), and perhaps even by working in scientific research or industrial engineering. Ultimately, the planet is on a kamikaze pathway that is being driven by us, and we all have a responsibility to do what we can to help pull it back onto a different track.

Patricia Thornley receives funding from EPSRC. She is the Editor in Chief of the journal Biomass & Bioenergy.

urn:contentItem:5RHD-DJD1-JD3N-53FB-00000-00BLISTERING State sizzles as mercury soars way up to 47C2018-01-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:58ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 9BLISTERING State sizzles as mercury soars way up to 47CPATRICK McDONALD MITCH MOTT

SPLASHING, sliding and sipping were among the top ways South Australians tried to beat the state's searing weekend heat, but it wasn't enough to help everyone keep their cool.

More than 50 volunteer firefighters were needed to contain a large forest fire south of Adelaide yesterday as temperatures soared.

The fire began just after 4pm in grassland and a tree plantation at Tooperang, near Goolwa, and was burning out of control before 11 CFS crews attended.

Water bombers and aerial surveillance aircraft provided support from above for the crews as they battled the fire in temperatures in the mid-30Cs.

SA Health said nine people presented to emergency departments across the state yesterday with heat-related illness, three of whom were admitted for further treatment. This was down from 16 people who sought treatment on Saturday. Six of these were admitted to hospital.

Temperatures reached 47C at Maree in the state's north at 4.07pm, with 46.6C recorded at Oodnadatta, 46.1 in Coober Pedy and Woomera and 46C at Moomba.

In Adelaide, it reached a sweltering 44.1C at Kent Town at 1.21pm, although the West Tce reading peaked at 41.8C at 11.53am.

Cloud cover was expected to keep last night's minimum to a fairly high 23C, before a cool change with showers and a maximum of 28C forecast for today and fine weather in the mid-to-high 20s for the rest of the working week. Up to 8mm of rain is forecast to fall in Adelaide today.

While some of the events at this year's Crush Festival at Adelaide Hills wineries were cancelled because of the extreme weather, those which went ahead still found plenty of patrons in search of a refreshing drink and shady vista.

Water activities remained a popular way to beat the heat.

At Moana Beach, Rachel Glendinning was celebrating her birthday with her daughter Scarlett, 2, and friends Jade and Adam Hicks, with their one-year-old daughter Sierra and son Brayden, 5.

In the northern suburbs, those with the energy to dance got to cool off with a dip between tracks with a DJ at Waterworld Aquatic Centre.

Waterslides and an inflatable obstacle course added to the activities for a big turnout at the Marion Outdoor Pool open day, where Sally Haynes and her sons Chaen, 8, and Jack, 12, joined the fun.

Although The Piece Project street art and music event at Longview Vineyard in Macclesfield was postponed due to the extreme weather, its star attraction, British DJ Norman Jay, instead played a Sunset Session last night for a sellout dance crowd on the River Torrens pontoon in Elder Park.

Also hit by the extreme heat, Victoria last night was struggling with widespread power blackouts.

The temperature in Melbourne at 9pm was still hovering in the mid-30s and almost 40,000 homes across the state were without power.

urn:contentItem:5N7N-96M1-F0JP-W37D-00000-00Burn-off warning2017-04-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:58ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 5Burn-off warningBethany Tyler

HEALTH experts are warning of a return of thunderstorm asthma-like symptoms as a large planned burn gets under way in the Otways.

In the wake of a bizarre January incident, in which nine people died after the weather brought on the respiratory disease in January, an Asthma Australia spokesman is advising residents to be prepared for environmental triggers such as smoke.

The warning comes as a 380ha hazard reduction burn between Lorne and Eastern View this week is set to create a visible column of smoke.

"It's technically the same mechanisms of the disease. The process, or trigger, whether it's from smoke resulting from burning wood or pollen inhaled into the lungs, the allergy has the same mechanics," Asthma Australia's Anthony Flynn said. "It triggers inflammation and a heightened and extreme inflammatory response in a person with asthma, with the narrowing of the airways and difficulty breathing." Mr Flynn advised sufferers to check their symptoms, use their preventer inhaler regularly, have a blue or grey reliever on them at all times and refer to their asthma management plan.

However he said given the controlled nature of planned burns, they were unlikely to cause the same widespread devastation as the "perfect storm" of thunderstorm asthma, occurring in the heavily populated Melbourne CBD.

Forest Fire Management Victoria crews are taking advantage of the mild weather conditions to reduce the risk of summer bushfires by igniting a number of planned burns in the Otways.

Residents are being advised a large column of smoke will be visible from Lorne to Aireys Inlet, which drivers are being told to ignore.

"As fire activity and smoke on the clifftops will be an eye-catching sight, we are asking drivers not to be distracted when driving along the Great Ocean Road," FFMV Otway district manager David Rourke said.

"This will not be a time to stop and take photos, but to focus on driving through the area, especially as smoke may affect visibility." The department is managing 100 burns across the state, with some under way, being patrolled or scheduled for ignition this week.

In the wake of the Christmas Day bushfires of 2015, Mr Rourke said providing protection for Lorne, Aireys Inlet, Fairhaven, Moggs Creek and Big Hill was a "high priority".

Aircraft, bulldozers, fire trucks and more than 60 firefighters will be involved in the multi-day operation.

"We will have significant resources at the planned burn including a Helitack waterbomber," Mr Rourke said."The waterbombing helicopter will assist fire crews to manage the fire in difficult terrain and ensure the safety of the Great Ocean Road." For further information on planned burns visit ffm.vic.gov.au/plannedburn or check out the VicEmergency app.

urn:contentItem:5P2W-G741-JD34-V412-00000-00'Big dry' points to early fire season2017-07-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:58ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 8'Big dry' points to early fire seasonPeter Hannam

Weather patterns delivering an exceptionally dry winter across south-eastern Australia show little sign of breaking up, heightening concerns the coming fire season will be an early and active one.

Fire authorities won't formally release predictions for spring and summer until September. Wet periods in autumn, though, curbed hazard-reduction burning to half the year-earlier totals in NSW and curtailed it in Victoria. Authorities stress a significant rain event could yet push fire risks for the coming season back towards more typical levels but note that there is little sign of such a development.

High-pressure systems have dominated southern Australia, nudging rain-bearing systems south of the continent.

Barring some unexpected instability, July will join last month as among Australia's driest. Nationally, last month was the second-driest June since standard data began in 1910 with rainfall barely a third of average, the Bureau of Meteorology said.

Victoria had its driest June, NSW was the driest in 15 years and the Murray Darling Basin posted its lowest rainfall totals since 1986.

"It very much seems to be centring on the border between Victoria and NSW," Richard Thornton, chief executive of the Bushfire and Natural Hazards Cooperative Research Centre, said of the rainfall deficits.

Winter-to-date rainfall levels have been "very much below average" for most of southern Australia, bureau data shows.

During the year to June 2017, Forest Fire Management Victoria crews conducted 351 burns over 113,172 hectares statewide. "The wet winter and spring conditions proved difficult, however our prioritisation of burns based on risk has resulted in the statewide risk being maintained at 2015-16 levels," said Stephanie Rotarangi, the agency's chief fire officer.

The key influence behind this year's relatively dry winter is far to the south. A positive phase in the so-called Southern Annular Mode marks a poleward contraction of the westerly winds belt towards Antarctica. As the bureau notes, such a phase marked the millennium drought during the "big dry" from 1997-2010. High-pressure systems that would normally sit further north track across more southerly parts of Australia blocking rain-bearing cold fronts.

In June, average mean sea level pressure readings were at record highs for many parts of southern Australia, including all but one site in South Australia and all but three in Victoria. As the bureau noted: "Mean sea level pressure over southern Australia has been increasing in winter over recent decades. This pattern is consistent with future climate change projections for the Australian region." Dr Thornton said that along with trends towards drier winters for southern Australia, warmer-than-average temperatures during July to September were also the new norm. "It's almost locked in to have above-average temperatures from climate change," he said.

urn:contentItem:5M8S-THM1-JD3N-52B2-00000-00ET exposed: just a big rubber puppet2016-11-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:58ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 29ET exposed: just a big rubber puppetMIRANDA MURPHY, MURPHY'S LORE

Sentimental classics a hard sell to new generation

Spoiler alert" â€¦ if you haven't seen it; trigger alert â€¦ if it makes you weep like a child.

We've been trying to wean our kids off animated movie schlock like Barbie and the Three Musketeers and Scooby Doo Solves the Kennedy Assassination.

It's not easy; they think that any piece of live-action film is basically the news and doubly boring.

But still we persist. And so we drew up a list of our favourite Gen Xer kids' movies that we hoped they would love too.

First cab off the rank: ET, The Extra Terrestrial.

When we showed our kids ET, we were prepared with tissues and life lessons. They came in handy for my husband and me, who sobbed like toddlers on the sofa. The kids, however, were strangely unmoved, except when the potplant looked like it needed water.

Were our offspring sociopaths?

Why weren't they doubled over with tears at the saddest, loveliest movie ever made?

Turns out they considered ET to be just a big rubber puppet. CGI animation has got that good that anything prior just looks lame.

We've given our childhood movie education a red-hot go, though. They loved Honey, I Shrunk The Kids, The Princess Bride, and the Star Wars movies - although when a major character got killed off our seven-year-old cried "Dad! You've taken me to the wrong movie!" That's the power of films, especially for kids.

Good triumphs over evil, orphans defeat the system, horrid comeuppances are delivered to wrongdoers.

Of course, you've got to be wary of the dark themes at work. Parental guidance is recommended, so when my kids asked to watch Bambi, I was both sentimental and wary.

I briefed them pre-screening on the early, traumatically tragic death of Bambi's mum.

"How does she die?" asked one of them, always keen on the fine print. "Um, I can't remember," I replied. "Maybe in the forest fire." After a bit, as I hovered in the kitchen waiting for emotional distress, one of the kids came bursting in, triumphantly exclaiming: "Mum! You were wrong! Bambi's mum didn't get caught in the fire - she was killed by hunters!"

Miranda Murphy is a mother of three and a journalist at The Australian.Follow her on Twitter @murphymiranda

urn:contentItem:5M90-SPH1-F0JP-W4P6-00000-00A rigorous screening process2016-12-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:58ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 15A rigorous screening processMIRANDA MURPHY - MURPHY'S LORE

Thanks in part to CGI, it's much harder to introduce little ones to the children's movies that you loved

Spoiler alert â€¦ if you haven't seen it; trigger alert â€¦ if it makes you weep like a child.

We've been trying to wean our kids off animated movie schlock like Barbie and the Three Musketeers and Scooby Doo Solves the Kennedy Assassination.

It's not easy; they think that any piece of live-action film is basically the news and doubly boring.

But still we persist.

And so we drew up a list of our favourite gen Xer kids' movies that we hoped they would love too.

First cab off the rank: ET, The Extra Terrestrial.

When we showed our kids ET, we were prepared with tissues and life lessons. They came in handy for my husband and me, who sobbed like toddlers on the sofa. The kids, however, were strangely unmoved, except when the potplant looked like it needed water.

Were our offspring sociopaths?

Why weren't they doubled over crying at the saddest, loveliest movie ever made? Turns out they considered ET to be just a big rubber puppet. CGI has got that good that anything prior looks lame.

We've given our childhood movie education a red-hot go, though. They loved Honey, I Shrunk The Kids, The Princess Bride, and the Star Wars movies - although when a major character got killed off our seven-year-old cried "Dad! You've taken me to the wrong movie!" That's the power of films, especially for kids.

Good triumphs over evil, orphans defeat the system, horrid comeuppances are delivered to wrongdoers.

Of course, you've got to be wary of some dark themes.

Parental guidance is recommended, so when my kids asked to watch Bambi, I was both sentimental and wary.

I briefed them pre-screening on the tragic death of Bambi's mum. "How does she die?" asked one of them, always keen on the fine print. "Um, I can't remember," I replied.

"Maybe in the forest fire." After a bit, as I hovered in the kitchen waiting for emotional distress, one of the kids came bursting in, triumphantly exclaiming: "Mum! You were wrong! Bambi's mum didn't get caught in the fire - she was killed by hunters!"Miranda Murphy is a mother of three and a journalist at The Australian.

urn:contentItem:5VC0-CFP1-JBJ7-N541-00000-00Lessons of Black Saturday ignored as Australians forget, research shows2019-02-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:58ZLexisNexisLessons of Black Saturday ignored as Australians forget, research showsLiam Mannix, Joshua Whittaker and Katharine Haynes

Despite a decade of reforms to the way we manage bushfire risk, another day like Black Saturday could lead to similar numbers of deaths, a top bushfire expert says.

Australians are still ignoring warnings to leave their homes on catastrophic fire days, 10 years after the Black Saturday bushfires left 173 people dead, new nationwide research finds.

And despite a decade of bushfire fighting reforms, another day like Black Saturday could lead to similar numbers of deaths, a top bushfire expert warns.

This comes as the Country Fire Authority's top officer warns Victorians: "We won't compromise the safety of our crew when you made a decision to stay there after we'd advised you to leave."

Black Saturday's fires flared up in the worst conditions in Australia's records. On February 7, 2009, a new record maximum temperature of 46.4??C was set in Melbourne, and the forest fire danger index reached 170, far higher than 1983's Ash Wednesday or 1939's Black Friday.

If we got a repeat those conditions, we could expect the same number of fatalities, says Professor Ross Bradstock, one of Australia's leading bushfire experts.

"If you were to replay the scenario, the weather, the ignition points and timing, I would say you'd get roughly the same result. All bets are off under those conditions. The sort of weather we saw, it was probably the worst fire weather in the world. It's a turbocharged furnace."

That did not suggest we'd learnt nothing from the disaster.

"We can tinker with our systems, our evacuations, our warnings. But it's so far off the scale, you have to question whether any of the things we do can make a difference."

The bushfire Royal Commission led to several key changes in the way we warn communities - warnings are sent via SMS and apps almost as soon as fires break out.

The biggest change has been the shift in messaging, away from a choice of 'stay or go', toward urging people to leave early.

On Black Saturday, even the most prepared residents found property defence challenging, and many were overwhelmed by fire.

Now, official advice on extreme fire danger days is that even the best prepared homes will not be safe, and that leaving the night before or early in the day is the safest option.

But research undertaken through the Bushfire & Natural Hazards CRC suggests that while the message may have changed since Black Saturday, people are still choosing to stay even when they are advised to leave.

A significant number of people tell researchers they simply won't leave until a bushfire breaks out nearby.

Many won't even leave if a bushfire does break out - waiting for it to directly threaten them before they take action.

This can lead to dangerous late evacuations, or being trapped at an unprepared property.

Some people remain unaware of bushfire risk and many do not, or can not, adequately plan and prepare for a bushfire.

The CFA wants to make it very clear: people who do not get out of harm's way cannot expect to be saved.

When a fire threatened houses in the Victorian spa town of Hepburn Springs on Saturday, police door-knocked 70 houses by 3am, urging people to leave.

"Even at that point, people chose to stay," says Steve Warrington, the CFA's chief officer.

"We made it really clear - we won't be sending a fire truck up your street. We won't compromise the safety of our crew when you made a decision to stay there after we'd advised you to leave."

Mr Warrington says there's only so much his firefighters can do.

"The big gap is the community not recognising what they have to do. Communities still think they are going to get a fire truck."

If Black Saturday were to happen again, "I suspect we will lose houses. But if people aren't there, we won't lose life," Mr Warrington said.

"I'd be devastated if people in Marysville and Kinglake were still in their houses on a Code Red day."

Dr Josh Whittaker is a bushfire researcher at the University of Wollongong and Dr Katharine Haynes is a human geographer at Macquarie University. Liam Mannix is The Age's science reporter.
