urn:contentItem:5GN8-2F21-JD34-V2NG-00000-00Burn-offs in doubt as strikes loom2015-08-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:58ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 2Burn-offs in doubt as strikes loomNick Toscano Workplace Reporter

Vital bushfire prevention works planned for next month are in doubt as the state government's professional forest firefighters raise the threat of strikes.

Several hundred fire workers employed by the Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning are considering taking action, including work stoppages, over their push to be recognised as emergency services personnel.

The matter risks becoming yet another industrial relations headache for the Andrews government, which is facing imminent public transport chaos as Metro and Yarra Trams workers also flag strikes

Victoria's departmental firefighters are the only professional fire workers in the state who are not classed as emergency services, and are denied what they say is ''vital recognition'' in equal rates of pay, superannuation and insurance for death and disability.

With negotiations for a new workplace deal at a stalemate, the Australian Workers Union, representing forest firefighters, said it was ready to ''take on'' the Andrews government.

State secretary Ben Davis said proposed industrial action could scuttle important plans for fuel reduction burns across forests before the bushfire season.

''We will vote on taking industrial action that minimises inconvenience to the community while maximising the impact,'' Mr Davis said.

A government spokeswoman said the department was in bargaining talks with the AWU. She said the planned spring burning program was part of the state's preparation for the coming fire season and would continue.

Mr Davis said the forest fire workers put their lives on the line as first responders to many major bushfires on public land and deserved better treatment. ''They work deep in the bush, far from media attention, performing some of the most dangerous tasks of all.''

The fire workers include firefighters, maintenance teams, look-out observers and expert ''rappel crews'', which abseil out of helicopters to battle blazes in otherwise inaccessible forest areas.

urn:contentItem:5M8J-XKC1-JD3N-51B9-00000-00ET exposed: just a big rubber puppet2016-11-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:58ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 18ET exposed: just a big rubber puppetMIRANDA MURPHY, MURPHY'S LORE

Sentimental classics a hard sell to new generation

Spoiler alert" â€¦ if you haven't seen it; trigger alert â€¦ if it makes you weep like a child.

We've been trying to wean our kids off animated movie schlock like Barbie and the Three Musketeers and Scooby Doo Solves the Kennedy Assassination.

It's not easy; they think that any piece of live-action film is basically the news and doubly boring.

But still we persist. And so we drew up a list of our favourite Gen Xer kids' movies that we hoped they would love too.

First cab off the rank: ET, The Extra Terrestrial.

When we showed our kids ET, we were prepared with tissues and life lessons. They came in handy for my husband and me, who sobbed like toddlers on the sofa. The kids, however, were strangely unmoved, except when the potplant looked like it needed water.

Were our offspring sociopaths? Why weren't they doubled over with tears at the saddest, loveliest movie ever made?

Turns out they considered ET to be just a big rubber puppet. CGI animation has got that good that anything prior just looks lame.

We've given our childhood movie education a red-hot go, though. They loved Honey, I Shrunk The Kids, The Princess Bride, and the Star Wars movies - although when a major character got killed off our seven-year-old cried "Dad! You've taken me to the wrong movie!" That's the power of films, especially for kids. Good triumphs over evil, orphans defeat the system, horrid comeuppances are delivered to wrongdoers.

Of course, you've got to be wary of the dark themes at work. Parental guidance is recommended, so when my kids asked to watch Bambi, I was both sentimental and wary.

I briefed them pre-screening on the early, traumatically tragic death of Bambi's mum.

"How does she die?" asked one of them, always keen on the fine print. "Um, I can't remember," I replied. "Maybe in the forest fire." After a bit, as I hovered in the kitchen waiting for emotional distress, one of the kids came bursting in, triumphantly exclaiming: "Mum! You were wrong! Bambi's mum didn't get caught in the fire - she was killed by hunters!" Miranda Murphy is a mother of three and a journalist at The Australian.Follow her on Twitter @murphymiranda

urn:contentItem:5VB7-K7P1-F031-X07P-00000-00Watch and Act warning issued for Grantville fire as authorities prepare for worsening conditions2019-02-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:58ZLexisNexisWatch and Act warning issued for Grantville fire as authorities prepare for worsening conditions

Victorian fire authorities are bracing for hot and windy weather on Sunday as they continue to fight fires which are threatening lives and properties in parts of the state.

An emergency warning has been downgraded back to Watch and Act for a number of communities around the Grantville Nature Reserve on the Bass Coast.

Residents in the Adams Estate and Grantville areas have been told to stay close to a building they can take shelter in, stay informed and monitor conditions, as the fire headed north towards Adams Estate late Sunday afternoon.

Yesterday,an emergency warning was issued for the same fire, before it was downgraded in the evening.

Earlier today, the threat eased for towns and communities further away as waterbombing aircraft worked on the fire into the early hours of this morning.

Emergency Management Commissioner Andrew Crisp said a total fire ban has been declared for the whole of the state on Sunday in anticipation of hot and windy conditions.

"Part of the reason for the declaration of the [total fire ban] is the fact we have so many fires going at the moment and we know that we can't afford to have too many more fires across the landscape across the state of Victoria," he said.

A cool change predicted to come through on Sunday evening could also pose problems for firefighters, with fears a wind change could shift the direction of the fire fronts.

Melbourne's water supply threatened

Meanwhile, authorities have warned a fire burning on the banks of Melbourne's largest dam for the past week could threaten the city's water supply.

Forest Fire Management Victoria state agency commander David Sayce said the blaze burning near the Thomson Catchment Complex, near Mount Baw Baw, had grown to 4,780 hectares and was still not under control.

"There's still a fair bit of smoke and quite active fire on this one ... we're really unsure what tomorrow's going to bring as it's not under control, it's likely to run under the conditions forecast," he said.

There are serious concerns firefighting efforts could inadvertently pollute the water supply, which receives little treatment before it is pumped into Victoria's water system.

"Immediately after a bushfire there is sediment run-off, ash, and erosion so that pollutes the waterways, and it can clog up water ways and impact the quality of water," the Australian National University's Chris Taylor told the ABC on Friday.

Victoria's Water Minister, Lisa Neville, said the state's water supply remained "absolutely safe" but authorities were still taking the blaze seriously.

"It has absolutely a risk to really impact our water supply in the short and long term, and that is why we are putting as many resources as we can to control the fire as much as possible," Ms Neville said.

Ms Neville said the Victorian Government was prepared to order water from the state's desalination plant in the event of supply concerns.

Fires burning on public land

Mr Grant said there are eight major fires burning on public land across the state.

He said the largest fire, which has been burning on remote land in Timbarra in East Gippsland for more than a week, covered 14,100 hectares and had approximately 300 firefighters working to bring it under control.

Mr Sayce said firefighters managed to stop another fire in Gippsland before it did any damage to nearby transmission and gas lines.

The bushfire started in Moondarra State Park and was travelling in a westerly direction towards Moe-Walhalla Road.

An emergency warning was also issued shortly after 4:00pm on Friday for a fire at Tanjil South, but authorities were able to slow the spread of that blaze, and it was downgraded to an advice message within hours.

"This was close to some critical infrastructure ... but the amazing work done by aviation, supported to by our ground crews, managed to contain this fire with little or no impact at all on any of that critical infrastructure," he said.

Mr Sayce said it had been a tough period for firefighters around the state, but efforts would continue.

"There's an element of fatigue because they've been at this for quite a while, and we're not out of the woods yet, but the resolve is quite high and they should be commended; they've managed to contain a huge number of fires in the past week," he said.

urn:contentItem:5M6W-MYT1-F0J6-J195-00000-00Too wet to burn, but set for fires2016-11-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:58ZLexisNexisToo wet to burn, but set for firesShana Morgan

Planned burns will not be part of preparations for the North East fire season this spring - it has simply been too wet.

More than 230 millimetres of rain has already fallen in Albury-Wodonga during the three months of spring, causing the ground to remain saturated for a long time.

Now warmer weather and windy conditions have arrived - including a forecast top of 35 degrees for Monday - the risk of fire is too high for the Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning to conduct burns.

Forest fire operations Hume manager Shaun Lawlor said spring burns usually only accounted for about 10 per cent of projects for the year, as conditions in the North East were better in autumn, but this year there would be none.

He assured residents the burns conducted over the past five years were still protecting their communities.

"The primary consideration this time of year is the weather and conditions typically aren't stable enough for planned burns," Mr Lawlor said. "We have had a couple of fires in previous weeks that has made us realise it's getting dry."

They included small incidents at Buffalo River and Shepparton.

DELWP staff were focused on the foothills and valleys of parkland, which would be under threat first before bushland dried out towards the end of summer.

"We already know we've got a lot of grass, when that dries out it will become fuel," Mr Lawlor said.

"Things could develop really quickly â€¦ if you can get to them when they're small, you've got a much better chance of getting them out.

DELWP, CFA, police and SES came together for a pre-season fire briefing in Benalla on Friday to plan for the months ahead.

Aircraft will be based at Albury again over the summer, plus DELWP will start using tougher G-wagon vehicles.

The four-wheel drives were designed to prevent a repeat of the tragedy at Harrietville in 2013 when two firefighters died after a tree fell on their vehicle.

"They offer us better protection, which is very close to our hearts, but they also carry greater water capacity," Mr Lawlor said.

Aviation services unit manager Brendan Zwanikken said a 12-month drone trial will be used for planned burning, firefighting, wildlife monitoring and rescues.

"All of the aircraft have the ability to fly up to 400 feet, within line of sight, and remain aloft for up to one hour," he said.

urn:contentItem:5N4F-JWT1-JD3N-51P2-00000-00Street Watch2017-03-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:58ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 7Street Watch

1 MOOROOLBARK Residents were lucky to escape injury after a semi-trailer rolled into the front garden of a Wainewright Ave property. Sergeant Jeff Haines said police were investigating circumstances leading up to when the truck collided into the house on March 16. Sgt Haines said police, CFA, SES, paramedics, Yarra Ranges Council and a heavy salvage had the truck off the scene by 8pm. He said police believe the semi-trailer began to roll down a steep hill after being unloaded about 3pm. Sgt Haines said the truck hit a parked car and a light pole before coming to rest against the veranda of the house. "Fortunately there were no injuries," he said. Anyone with information is being urged to contact Mooroolbark Police on 9725 9999 or Crime Stoppers.

2 LILYDALE A Lilydale man will front the Ringwood Magistrates Court later this year charged with stealing a car. Police charged the 35-year-old after allegedly finding him inside a stolen Subaru Impreza, with false numberplates in the York on Lilydale hotel carpark just after midnight on March 8.

3 BIG PATS CREEK Lightning is believed to have started a bushfire that took CFA and State Government firefighters about four hours to control. Emergency services were called to the Lyrebird Rd fire that burned about 1ha of bushland about 7.40pm on Saturday, March 11. Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning Forest Fire Management Victoria State Agency commander David Sayce said firefighters had the blaze under control by 11.35pm.

4 YARRA GLEN A female duo allegedly stole a VicRoads car only minutes after stealing from another vehicle in Yarra Glen. Police are on the hunt for the two women who were seen driving away after allegedly stealing a service book from inside a car on Bell St about 2.45pm on March 16. Yarra Glen Sergeant Richard Coulson said one woman smashed the car's window to get to the records. The car was parked behind the main street shops. Sgt Coulson said the owner of the vehicle discovered a woman rummaging in the car before she ran away when confronted. He said the woman then hopped into a small white late model hatch back - driven by another woman - believed to be a stolen Hyundai Elantra, which sped off along Healesville Yarra Glen Rd on the Yarra Glen Bypass. Sgt Coulson said the same women stopped along the bypass and stole a VicRoads white Ford Territory, with distinctive roof mounted orange flashing lights, and registration plate MCY467. Sgt Coulson said police believe the numberplate on the Elantra started with 1BP. Both women are in their early 20s, with black hair and clothes. Contact Crime Stoppers or Yarra Glen Police on 9730 1296.

urn:contentItem:5TGD-8081-F0J6-J0MX-00000-00NZ gives lessons on climate change2018-10-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:58ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 10NZ gives lessons on climate changePeter Hannam

Scott Simpson, New Zealand's National Party environment spokesman, stunned a trans-Tasman investment meeting last week by stating that climate action was "too important to be playing politics with".

Or rather, it was the Australian delegates who were shocked, so used are they to the toxic debate in Canberra.

"It made my jaw drop, that's for sure," said Emma Herd, chief executive of the Investor Group on Climate Change.

Also well received was Mr Simpson's comment that it was vital "for all of us and our grandchildren that we have a [climate action] framework that is enduring", coming as it did soon after the UN's Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change had issued its latest report warning of the perils of even another half degree of warming.

That Mr Simpson hails from the centre-right opposition party roughly equivalent to our Liberal-National coalition only underscored the contrast between the nations.

New Zealand's major parties, busy trying to thrash out a Zero Carbon Bill by year's end, are dismayed by the absence of similar bipartisanship across the Tasman, James Shaw, climate change minister in the Labour-led government said.

"We do tend to look at what's going on in Australia politics, in particular in relation to climate policies, and we think, 'We cannot afford to let this happen in New Zealand'," Mr Shaw said. "It seems like a pretty strong lesson in what not to do."

Despite ditching its main climate and energy policy - the National Energy Guarantee aimed at reducing carbon emissions from the power sector while bolstering the grid and easing prices - the Morrison government insists it can meet Australia's Paris climate commitments.

Even if total emissions were the issue, Kiwis would have more excuse than Australians for doing nothing. Their share of global greenhouse gases is less than 0.2 per cent, or about a eighth of Australia's.

Still, on a per capita basis, both nations have among the world's highest emissions, Mr Shaw said.

Tally up the 90-odd nations contributing less than 1 per cent of emissions and you reach almost a third of the global total - larger than China or the US, he said. "An issue like this is something the whole world has to grapple with," Todd Muller, Mr Shaw's counterpart from the National Party, said.

To remove the politics from the negotiations, all sides agreed to take advice on New Zealand's targets from an independent climate commission.

"If you have essentially your best and your brightest informed by science ... it's an easier place to have a conversation with your community than just playing partisan politics with them," Mr Muller said.

Mr Shaw said the opposition could have exploited a potentially divisive policy - agriculture contributes half of New Zealand's greenhouse gas emissions - but did not.

"They are playing an absolute straight bat," he said.

New Zealanders, like Australians, have endured increasing extreme weather. These include a record hot year in 2016, droughts and a major forest fire last year.

"We've definitely had a lot more extreme rainfall events," Nava Fedaeff, a climate scientist with the National Institute of Water and Atmospheric Research (NIWA), said.

Farmers, who have in the past objected fiercely to taxes on methane, appear more ready to accept the need to act. DairyNZ, for instance, has welcomed the prospect of emissions targets enshrined in legislation to give the sector "much needed certainty".

Mr Shaw said one reason for the different response was that farmers - unlike Australian coal companies - had options.

"People are still going to want to eat in 30 years' time, so the question is what do you produce and how do you produce it - not whether or not you're going to produce food," he said. "But in 30 years' time, you can pretty much guarantee no one in the world is going to use coal for anything."

urn:contentItem:5XKW-HPX1-JD34-V01V-00000-00Letters to the Editor2019-11-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:58ZLexisNexisOPINIONPg. 8Letters to the Editor

Open the fire trails A message to Prime Minister Scott Morrison, David Gillespie MP, NSW Premier Gladys Berejiklian, Leslie Williams MLA, Melinda Pavey MLA and Mayor Peta Pinson:

You must listen to the people, to what is being said the print, on the radio and on social media. People are hurting so badly from these fires. They are telling such heart-wrenching stories of grief; they have lost their homes, their farms and livelihoods, their stock, fences, sheds and machinery. They have fought so hard to save their farms.

Dairy farmers are milking with a generator and the raw milk is going down the drain. They have no power to cool the milk. Other people are grieving for loved ones killed in the fires. People are anxious and suffering from great trauma.

Many are saying the fires come from the enormous fuel build-up in our forests. The fires are a fire storm. They are described as apocalyptic by those who have escaped from them. We live in a catastrophic fire danger area. It is frightening. Forests around us have not been burnt in 20 or more years. The right conditions and we could have a fire storm.

The mayor of Greater Taree City Council, Paul Hogan, spoke passionately to Alan Jones on Facebook. He said we should:

Open the fire trails in the forests, so the firefighters can access the fires IMMEDIATELY. We have summer yet to come. Form a Forest Fire Control Authority made up of knowledgeable, experienced people (senior firefighters?) to monitor the fuel load in the forests. Where it exceeds 25 tonnes per hectare, have a cool fire burn (in winter) to keep the fuel load under control. This would kill no animals. Give this authority the money and resources to do the job. Give this authority complete authority to do its job, over and above the authority of the national parks. Open the forests to cattle-grazing. Some native plants have seeds that need to pass through a fire to germinate. Native wildlife are killed en masse - burnt alive. It is so sad and needless.

The NSW Rural Fire Service men and woman, and the volunteers, are so brave and skilled and they are my heroes. The pilots have such a dangerous job, low-flying, in smoke, so many of them working together, and coming down and taking off all day? Thank you to all the volunteers who feed the firies.

We voted you people to office to look after us and our land. Are you doing that? Don't let all this die down and settle back to comfort until the next fire season arrives. Listen to what the people are saying. Please.

Penelope McKinnon, Sancrox

Put weir on bridge This letter, which I have sent to Mayor Peta Pinson, raises the matter of sustainable water supply for the Hastings Valley and beyond out to our boundaries.

Seeing that our supply only comes from the Koree Island pumping station and can only pump when all the factors are favourable, I wish to put forward my idea of placing a weir on the river. If placed above Bain's Bridge it would give much more water available to the pumping station than at present and would enrich the quality of water taken from the Hastings River.

The weir would only need to be a little bit more than a metre high, and there are a few deep holes on the lower side of the pumping station which could enhance the weir's existence.

In the Wauchope Gazette dated October 24, farmer Dennis Pelham wasd standing on gravel above water level which used to be above his head when there was sufficient water in the river. I submit papers which lay out the different constructions of weirs and the availability of fish and water creature's access to the higher reaches of the river to which the council could adapt.

If we advance the advice from experts we could act now and put in place a weir while the river is low and reap the benefits for years to come. On another note, there is the Blue Creek Dam that has been decommissioned years ago and I ask the question: would it be able to get it up and running just to service the town of Wauchope itself?

I know that in hard times we need to look to the future and install measures that are sensible and have long benefits for our region, please consider this request.

Greg Elliott, Wauchope

Thanks to Show Society My partner and I recently camped at the Wauchope Showground to ensure our horses were safe from the fire threat.

We can't thank the volunteers enough for the facilities and support they provided. Volunteers worked tirelessly. Some of the amazing people that we met included Scott, Heather, Neil, Maree and Wendy. There were others whose names we never learned.

Volunteers stayed overnight, fed animals, organised supplies, cleaned facilities, managed donations, coped with large amounts of paperwork requested by government, cooked tirelessly and did many unseen tasks.

On Monday, when many more animals arrived than could be accommodated in the existing facilities, they organised additional steel pens to be delivered and erected. They managed stressed people and animals with tact and compassion. They created order out of a chaotic situation.

We are so grateful that we were able to use the existing wooden stalls for our four horses. The stalls are old and in need of repair, but we don't know what we would have done if we had not been able to use them.

One of our ponies is blind so we couldn't just put him in an agistment paddock. The existing wooden horse stall facilities were vital. We would like to express our sincere thanks and admiration to the volunteers of the Wauchope Show Society.

Carol Booth, Lorne

urn:contentItem:5V9C-FRP1-JBJ7-N367-00000-00'Very high' fire danger: High temperatures to again scorch the state2019-01-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:58ZLexisNexis'Very high' fire danger: High temperatures to again scorch the stateSophie Aubrey

It comes less than a week after extreme heat left hundreds of thousands of Victorians without power.

High temperatures are once again set to scorch the state less than a week after a stint of extreme heat left hundreds of thousands of Victorians without power.

Bureau of Meteorology senior forecaster Tom Delamotte said temperatures were expected to heat up across Victoria into the mid-to-high 30s on Tuesday and Wednesday. It comes after more than 200,000 Victorians had their electricity switched off on Friday when temperatures were in the 40s, in response to depleted power reserves.

However, a spokesman for the Australian Energy Market Operator said power reserve levels were more robust than they were last week.

"There will be greater resources available to us," he said. "We are also not anticipating the demand to reach the levels it did [on Friday]."

However, this week's rising temperatures are putting pressure on firefighters who are continuing to try to bring five active bushfires under control.

Melbourne's CBD is expected to swelter at 37 degrees on Tuesday and 36 degrees on Wednesday, with similar temperatures being forecast throughout the state.

Mr Delamotte warned that the high temperatures paired with north-westerly winds were making for a dangerous mix for firefighting efforts.

"Those two factors combining make the fire danger very high across much of Victoria today," Mr Delamotte said.

"As we move into Wednesday we're going to see a cold front approach later in the day from the west. With that, winds will become fresh and gusty."

Severe fire danger ratings will be in place in the Mallee, Wimmera and south-west districts on Wednesday.

There is also a risk of thunderstorms through eastern and central parts of the state, bringing the threat of lightning-caused fires.

Meanwhile, Victoria's firefighting fleet has been reduced by two after authorities were forced to ground a second aircraft after a water-bombing helicopter fighting fires in Gippsland crashed into a dam.

Two pilots and an engineer were inside the aircrane when it crashed into the water during operations over the Thomson Complex Catchment fires in Gippsland about 7.15pm on Monday. All three occupants were able to swim to safety to the edge of the dam and an investigation into the accident's cause is under way.

The helicopter is one of two such aircranes in Victoria, and both have now been grounded to conduct safety checks and ensure there is no systemic issue with the model of aircraft.

Forest Fire Management Victoria state agency commander David Nugent said the aircranes were a crucial part of the state's firefighting fleet, which is made up of 49 contracted aircraft, due to their high water-holding capacity.

The aircranes are the largest helicopters, able to carry 7500 litres, compared to medium helicopters, which hold up to 3000 litres, and fixed-wing air tankers that take up to 15,000 litres.

A State Control Centre spokeswoman said other aircraft had been redeployed to account for the two grounded helicopters, with crews "confident" there was sufficient aircraft in the air to continue to fight fires.

Mr Nugent said of the five fires still burning, the largest was the 13,084-hectare blaze near Timbarra in East Gippsland. The fire has destroyed a caravan, a shed and several kilometres of fencing. It will be the blaze most susceptible to a gusty wind change on Wednesday due to its 1000-metre elevation, according to Mr Delamotte.

There are also three large active fires in the Thomson Complex Catchment area and another further north near Mansfield.

"There have been a number of other fires over the last week or two and while many of those are contained, we still have to make sure they don't escape again as the weather risk increases," Mr Nugent said.

Mr Nugent said there were currently up to 2000 firefighters working on the bushfires.

"We'll be putting all our efforts to doing all we can today and tomorrow as the weather creates greater risk for us," Mr Nugent said.

Cooler conditions are expected to sweep the state on Thursday after a temperature drop some time between late Wednesday and the early hours of Thursday morning.

However, the relief will be short-lived, with another heat cycle forecast to begin on the weekend.

"Hot northerly winds will jump us back up into the high 30s on Saturday and low 40s for inland areas," Mr Delamotte said.

urn:contentItem:5X58-V1J1-JD3N-51B1-00000-00Braced for a deadly summer of fires2019-09-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:58ZLexisNexisTHENATIONPg. 5Braced for a deadly summer of firesMATTHEW DENHOLM, EXCLUSIVE

The bushfires in NSW and Queensland this month may be just a taste of an expected horror nationwide fire season, as experts and former fire chiefs warn agencies risk being "overwhelmed".

Forecasters say many parts of the country face above average fire risk and there is concern longer, overlapping bushfire seasons may prevent vital resource sharing between states during crises.

Experts and former fire chiefs are calling for a rethink of Australia's approach to bushfires, including community fire shelters, tougher building standards and a new role for government and the Australian Defence Force.

"The conditions are getting worse. With overlapping fire seasons (between states) we are going to be caught short," former NSW Fire and Rescue commissioner Greg Mullins told The Australian.

"In the first week of September we had catastrophic fire conditions in NSW and Queensland, which was unprecedented. We are in the middle of a drought and all the seasonal outlooks from the Bureau of Meteorology are saying 'drier and hotter'.

"If we don't get rain â€¦ and we get a simultaneous east coast bad fire day in Queensland, NSW, ACT, Victoria, South Australia, Tasmania, we won't be able to share resources. There won't be enough aircraft. There won't be enough firefighters. There won't be enough firetrucks. I can see a situation where the fire services will be overwhelmed." Former longstanding Tasmanian chief fire officer Mike Brown was concerned overlapping fire seasons were making it more difficult for jurisdictions to loan each other resources and personnel.

"Hotter and drier conditions mean we are getting three, four or all states having very serious fire conditions at the same time and so they are less able to release resources to another jurisdiction," Mr Brown said.

"On quite a few occasions, Australia has got assistance from the US but their fire season is now running hard up and into our fire season as well." The latest seasonal bushfire outlook, developed by the Bushfire and Natural Hazards CRC with BOM and fire agencies, suggests a simultaneous, multi-jurisdictional bushfire crisis is possible this summer.

It finds unusually dry and warm conditions have created "above normal fire potential" across "the east coast of Queensland, NSW, Victoria and Tasmania as well as parts of Western Australia and South Australia".

BOM meteorologist David Wilke said the latest climate outlook, released on Thursday, only reinforced this elevated fire danger: "There is a strong chance October will be drier than average for most of Australia, with the dry expected to persist for much of central and eastern Australia until at least the end of 2019." Bushfire and Natural Hazards CRC chief executive Richard Thornton warned significant population areas were facing elevated risks. "The areas at elevated risk this year incorporate a lot of the populated areas around the country - Brisbane, most coastal areas of NSW and into Gippsland, areas around Perth, and areas that have large holiday populations," he said.

Even those not at heightened risk could not rest easy: "In areas we didn't paint red there's still a normal fire year. We need to be a bit more vigilant this year." Dr Thornton said the severity of the early September bushfires should be a wake-up call.

"People further south coming into their fire season in the next few weeks should take a look at what's happening across the rest of the country," Dr Thornton said.

"Now is the time to really start thinking about what you are going to do on those really bad fire danger days. What is your plan?

"Research shows, from the Blue Mountains to northern NSW, Black Saturday, and the Perth hills, it's universal: people impacted by bushfires say 'we knew it was a risky area but we didn't think it was a problem for us'." Another BOM report this week showed the number of high-fire-danger days in September had increased across eastern Australia since the 1950s.

As well, the first day of high fire danger had come forward by as much as a month in parts of NSW.

A BOM analysis of the daily Forest Fire Danger Index - the key indicator of the severity of fire weather conditions - shows "an increasing length and intensity of the fire season" nationally.

Experts and fire chiefs said such trends were reducing the time and resources available to conduct essential pre-season burns.

"The window for ideal fuel reduction gets reduced and the opportunities become less and less," Mr Brown said.

"Staff and volunteers are fatigued. You can have firefighting and fuel reduction going on at the same time." Mr Mullins believed the federal government could no longer dismiss firefighting as a state responsibility and a national summit may be needed to develop strategies to deal with the worsening, evolving bushfire threat.

"The federal government pays one-tenth of the cost of our national fleet of firefighting aircraft. They put in $15m of $160m (for major firefighting aircraft). That restricts how many we can have here," he said.

"I and other fire chiefs believe the federal government should be putting in more money." While he did not want to see ADF personnel fighting fires, Mr Mullins said defence could provide logistical support, from remote sensing to refuelling fire trucks.Several experts urged a tougher Australian standard for building in bushfire-prone areas, while Mr Mullins, one of the nation's most experienced fire chiefs with almost 40 years of service, said there might be a need for fire shelters.

urn:contentItem:5TGD-8081-F0J6-J0SK-00000-00Kiwis offer lessons in tackling climate change2018-10-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:58ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 10Kiwis offer lessons in tackling climate changePeter Hannam

Playing politics with the environment is something New Zealand will not do, writes Peter Hannam.

Scott Simpson, New Zealand's National Party environment spokesman, stunned a trans-Tasman investment meeting last week by stating that climate action was "too important to be playing politics with".

Or rather, it was the Australian delegates who were shocked, so used are they to the toxic debates in Canberra. "It made my jaw drop, that's for sure," said Emma Herd, chief executive of the Investor Group on Climate Change.

Also well received was Mr Simpson's comment that it was vital "for all of us and our grandchildren that we have a [climate action] framework that is enduring", coming as it did soon after the UN's Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change had issued its latest report, warning about the perils of even another half degree of warming.

That Mr Simpson hails from the centre-right opposition party roughly equivalent to our Liberal-National coalition only underscored the contrast between the nations.

New Zealand's major parties, busy trying to thrash out a Zero Carbon Bill by year's end, are dismayed by the absence of similar bipartisanship across the Tasman, James Shaw, climate change minister in the Labor-led government, told Fairfax Media.

"We do tend to look at what's going on in Australia politics, in particular in relation to climate policies, and we think, 'We cannot afford to let this happen in New Zealand'," Mr Shaw said. "It seems like a pretty strong lesson in what not to do."

Even if total emissions were the issue, Kiwis would have more excuse than Australians for doing nothing. Their share of global greenhouse gases is less than 0.2 per cent, or about an eighth, of Australia's. Still, on a per-capita basis, both nations have among the highest emissions in the world, Mr Shaw said.

Tally up the 90-odd nations contributing less than 1 per cent of emissions and you reach almost a third of the global total - larger than China or the US, he said.

"An issue like this is something the whole world has to grapple with," Todd Muller, Mr Shaw's counterpart from the National Party, said.

To remove the politics from the negotiations, all sides agreed to take advice on New Zealand's targets from an independent climate commission.

"If you have essentially your best and your brightest informed by science ... it's an easier place to have a conversation with your community than just playing partisan politics with them," Mr Muller said.

Mr Shaw said the Opposition could have exploited a potentially divisive policy - agriculture contributes half of New Zealand's greenhouse gas emissions - but didn't.

"They are playing an absolute straight bat," he said.

New Zealanders, like Australians, have endured an increasing spate of extreme weather events. These include a record hot year in 2016, droughts and a major forest fire last year.

Farmers, who have in the past objected fiercely to taxes on methane, appear more ready to accept the need to act. DairyNZ, for instance, has welcomed the prospect of emissions targets enshrined in legislation to give the sector "much needed certainty".

Trish Rankin, a dairy farmer managing 440 cows for a Maori-owned co-operative near Hawera in the Taranaki region of the North Island, said climate action "needs to be apolitical - it needs to be able to last over time".

Ms Rankin said New Zealand farmers realise their social licence depends on them being good custodians of the land, and the principle extends to curbing emissions. Open consultations with experts have also helped.

Mr Shaw said one reason for the different response is that farmers - unlike Australian coal companies - have options.

"People are still going to want to eat in 30 years' time, so the question is what do you produce and how do you produce it - not whether or not you're going to produce food," he said. "But in 30 years' time, you can pretty much guarantee no one in the world is going to use coal for anything."

urn:contentItem:5V9C-PF11-F031-X0JC-00000-00Aircrane firefighting helicopter was 'performing normally' before crashing into Gippsland dam2019-01-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:58ZLexisNexisAircrane firefighting helicopter was 'performing normally' before crashing into Gippsland dam

The company operating a firefighting helicopter that crashed into a dam in eastern Victoria says the aircraft was "performing normally" moments before the accident.

Two pilots and one engineer were on board the Aircrane when it crashed into a dam at Jericho, in remote Gippsland, just after 7:00pm Monday.

The three men managed to swim to the edge of the dam.

Emergency Management Commissioner Andrew Crisp said the chopper "landed heavily" and the crew was flown to the Latrobe Valley Hospital for treatment.

"They were examined for some minor injuries and shock, as you'd imagine, but I believe they've been released from hospital now," he told ABC Radio Melbourne.

He said the cause of the crash was not yet clear.

Fleet grounded as 'precaution'

The Aircrane helicopter is one of the largest water-bombing aircraft in the world, and Victoria contracts two Aircranes as part of its firefighting fleet.

Five similar Aircranes - in NSW, South Australia, Western Australia and Victoria - were grounded while the crash was investigated.

Kestrel Aviation managing director Ray Cronin, whose company manages the fleet, said the ground was a "precautionary measure" while the company interviewed the crew and determined a probable cause.

He said after an initial investigation, the company and authorities had agreed that the grounding of the Aircrane fleet would be lifted.

"The Aircranes will return to service almost immediately," Mr Cronin said.

"The crews are with the aircraft ready to rejoin the fire fight in Victoria."

He said while he did not want to pre-empt the outcome of the Australian Transport Safety Bureau's (ATSB) investigation, he understood "the serviceability of the Aircrane" was good at the time of the crash.

"These environments are very challenging, very dynamic, and we are confident that the aircraft was performing normally up to the point of impact," he said.

"[I'm] absolutely confident in the aircraft - they're a workhorse, they're a very reliable aircraft."

A 'hazardous operating environment'

The Aircrane was refilling its water at the time, Forest Fire Management Victoria deputy fire officer Darrin McKenzie said.

"So they're actually quite close to water at that point. They have a snorkel which drops down into the water. They haven't fallen a great distance before they impacted with the water," Mr McKenzie said.

He said it was a "hazardous operating environment".

"This dam is surrounded by trees, and surrounded by hills. But it is quite rare that we have an event like this," he said.

"So they have to be really careful about what the wind conditions are, any downdrafts. So wind and visibility are the key things they need to think about from a safety view."

Work will begin in the next few days to try and work out how to get the Aircrane out of the water.

Crash 'very unusual' for renowned Aircrane

With a water-holding capacity of up to 9,000 litres, the Aircrane is popular with firefighting agencies around the world, CFA incident controller Mike Owen said.

"They're renowned across the world for their large firefighting capability and they operate in the USA, Canada, Australia, Greece, France and there's a fleet of about 20 of these worldwide at any time operating across firefighting," he told ABC Radio Gippsland.

"So very specialist equipment, very reliable, and Erickson are a well-known, well-respected company that operates them."

Each Aircrane is worth about $30 million, which Mr Owen said indicated the "sophistication" and "reliability" of the aircraft.

"It's very, very unusual to have an incident like this," he said.

Hundreds of hectares continue to burn

The helicopter was one of 10 water bombers being used to contain the Thomson Catchment Complex fires, which are burning just north of Mount Baw Baw.

Mr Owen said the fires were in a rugged area, making it difficult to get equipment into the area.

"There are three fires that are in the catchment ... and together they're about 700 to 800 hectares at the moment," he said.

"[Monday] was the start of a concerted effort to use lots of aircraft bombing it, trying to create lines and assisting firefighters on the ground when we can get them in."

Premier Daniel Andrews said the crash was "a really serious incident" and said any lessons learnt during the investigation would be taken on board.

"We're very pleased obviously that nobody was seriously injured. It could've been a very different outcome," he said.

WorkSafe has been notified of the crash.

urn:contentItem:5M44-1SP1-JD34-V48F-00000-00Fire services face an uphill battle2016-11-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:58ZLexisNexisAPg. 10Fire services face an uphill battle

By Esther Lauaki

A failure to meet fuel reduction targets before the fire season sets in has sparked a call for the state government to take urgent action.

Northern Victoria Liberal MP Wendy Lovell is urging more action to safeguard residents and their properties this fire season.

Ms Lovell last week criticised the Andrews government for poor management of pre-season fuel loads, citing its failure to meet burn targets.

An Environment, Land, Water and Planning department report has found the state only achieved 72 per cent of the target this winter, and is facing an uphill battle to meet its targets for the forthcoming fire season.

Ms Lovell has called on the state government to take immediate action to protect Victorians from the coming fire season, which is expected to be high risk.

"The risk of serious fire incidents for this summer has increased significantly due to the state government's failure to adequately meet fuel reduction targets," the MP said. "[This] has resulted in unacceptably high levels of fuel load remaining in Victorian forests going into the 2016-17 bushfire season.

"The Royal Commission findings identified the importance of fuel reduction in decreasing fuel loads to reduce the spread and intensity of bushfires.

"[It] also found that excessive fuel loads add to the likelihood of more intense bushfires ... thereby placing firefighters and communities at greater risk.

"The report went on to say that the state should achieve prescribed burning of an annual rolling target of a minimum of five per cent of public land each year, and that the state be held accountable for meeting this target," Ms Lovell said.

Forest Fire Management Victoria district manager Paul Bates said slashing has already started on about 1500 hectares of public land in central Victoria this season. Mr Bates said the work has been slightly delayed due to significant rain in the region over recent months.

"Forecasts for the summer show that parts of central Victoria are at above average risk of grassfire due to the increase in growth.

"Reducing bushfire risk is a shared responsibility," he said. "Reducing fuel loads on public land can only do so much - communities and households need to know how to be prepared and reduce their bushfire risk on their properties.

"Our modelling shows a significant amount of bushfire risk is on privately owned land because of thick vegetation and high populations," Mr Bates said.

"We encourage homeowners to be prepared ... by clearing space around their house of all flammable materials."

Report risk concerns to DELWP on 136 186.

urn:contentItem:4P78-17J0-TXN5-S1XN-00000-00It's catastrophic: environmentally and economically2006-10-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:58ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 5It's catastrophic: environmentally and economicallyTHE LONG HOT DRYSTEPHEN CAUCHIE

The big dry has lasted 10 years so far and could go on for longer. Stephen Cauchi asks the experts to predict the consequences.

LESS water, ruined farms, more bushfires. That's the gloomy forecast if Victoria's drought continues. Unfortunately, there's a good chance it will.

It is 10 years to the month since the drought began in southern and eastern Australia. For Victoria, it has been the second-driest 10-year period in history, just behind 1935-45. For the region around Melbourne, it has been the driest-ever such period.

"If it continues on for another five, we wouldn't be calling it a drought any more. We'd be thinking about a change in climate," said National Climate Centre meteorologist Robert Fawcett.

As a precedent, Dr Fawcett points to the south-western tip of Western Australia, which has been notably drier since 1970. "The climate shifted to a drier regime and that may well be happening here."

So where will the impact be felt the most?

Water supplies

The most recent CSIRO/Melbourne Water study predicts that less rainfall will mean Melbourne's water supplies could be cut by between 4 and 15 per cent by 2020, while demand for water will increase due to the city's expanding population.

The Government's plan to deal with this is to reconnect Tarago Reservoir, which was taken offline in 1994 due to poor water quality. A treatment plant will be built to ensure the water is drinkable.

Permanent water restrictions will continue. Other measures that may have to be considered, according to the study, include desalination plants; harvesting stormwater, including storing it in large underground aquifers for non-drinking purposes; and recycling treated effluent for drinking water. There will be an acute need for these measures by 2050, when supplies will be down 10 to 40 per cent compared with today.

Farming

The prospect of the drought continuing for another five years is a "frightening thought", according to Victorian Farmers Federation president Simon Ramsey. "Assuming that we have broad-brush drought right across Australia . . . it's going to be catastrophic. It will mean that we have real difficulty in food production . . . livestock will be decimated."

Mr Ramsey said Australia would still be able to feed itself, but the current account deficit would suffer, as would Victoria's financial health. "It's more the export market than the dom-estic supply (that will be harmed), given we're a net exporter. Financially, it's going to be a disaster as part of the trade deficit."

As irrigated water dried up in the state's north, whole farm sectors were at risk, he said. "Most of our dairy is in the north . . . we won't have a dairy industry after that."

Farmers will walk off the land, taking with them the rural workforce - labourers, shearers, tractor drivers. "We believe we're going to lose about 10 to 15 per cent in this drought. If you're talking five to 10 years, it may well contract 50 per cent. Farmers will either walk off or sell off. All the little towns will be reduced to a few shops . . . it's a pretty gloomy picture."

Bushfires

There will be more bushfires, says the Bushfire Co-operative Research Centre, CSIRO and Bureau of Meteorology. The three last year wrote a report, Climate change impacts on fire-weather in south-east Australia, which models likely bushfire behaviour to 2050.

Bushfires are caused by other factors besides hot weather - including fuels, terrain, land management and firefighting response - so it restricts predictions to the num-ber of "fire-weather" days likely to trigger or fuel bushfires.

The report predicts the num-ber of days when the risk of a forest fire or grassfire is "extreme" or "very high". Pre-dictions are based on data from 17 locations in south-eastern Australia, including Melbourne, Laverton, Sale, Bendigo and Mildura.

"The study found that the increase in fire-weather risk is generally largest inland.

"The combined frequency of days with very high and extreme forest fire danger index ratings are likely to increase in south-east Australia by 4 to 25 per cent by 2020 and 15 to 70 per cent by 2050."

Around Melbourne, there are on average nine days a year when there is very high or extreme risk of forest fire, and 38 days when there is extreme or very high risk of grassfire.

By 2020, the report predicts, this will increase to 11 days for forest fire, and up to 45 days for grassfire.

By 2050, it could rise to 14 and 54 days respectively.

urn:contentItem:5CWN-9741-JCBD-901T-00000-00LENDING A HAND2014-08-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:58ZLexisNexisAPg. 10LENDING A HANDThe Chronicle

A pair of Canberran firefighters are on their way to Canada to assist authorities with the fight against the worst forest fire season in decades.

Forest fires in British Columbia have destroyed close to 200,000 hectares of land this season which is the largest area of land burnt in the province since the 1950s.

The pair of firefighters will assist with back-burning and ignition operations for up to five weeks.

Police and Emergency Services Minister Simon Corbell said Brett McNamara and Andrew Halley from the ACT Rural Fire Service Parks Brigade flew out of Canberra on Sunday afternoon.

An international call for help was issued by Canadian firefighting authorities who were close to exhausting their internal resources.

Australia received notification from the Canadian Interagency Fire Fighting Centre that wildfire conditions had deteriorated in the Canadian province of British Columbia on August 4.

A formal request was made for resources on August 5 and the ACT was approached to form part of an Australian contingent.

Eighty Australians will fly to the Canadian province in the coming days including more than 50 firefighters from Victoria. “It is likely that the ACT personnel will be deployed to Kamloops in south British Columbia or to Prince George in Central British Columbia,” Mr Corbell said.

“British Columbia currently has high to extreme wild land fire hazards with more than 170 out of control or uncontained wildfires burning across the province.” Mr Corbell said more than 198,000 hectares had been burnt out representing the largest area burnt at this time of year since 1958.

urn:contentItem:5V5S-6961-F031-X0MV-00000-00Rosedale firefighters prepare for possible bushfire flare-up over weekend2019-01-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:58ZLexisNexisRosedale firefighters prepare for possible bushfire flare-up over weekendBy Beth Gibson

A fire that began in Rosedale, in Victoria's Gippsland, one week ago has now burnt more than 12,000 hectares of state forest and plantations.

Authorities are particularly concerned about the hot weather forecast for this weekend with temperatures higher than 35 degrees Celsius also predicted for Monday and Tuesday.

"We are anticipating that there will be increased smoke coming out of the fire over today, tomorrow, and into the warmer period next week," said Department of Environment, Land Water and Planning regional controller Ben Rankin.

Monitoring fire perimeter ahead of hot weekend

An 80-kilometre containment line has been established around the perimeter of the fire, but authorities are warning that sections could still ignite in bad conditions.

Forest Fire Management Victoria operations officer Darryl Burns said about 300 firefighters were working day and night to put out potential spot fires and flare-ups.

"We've got a number of tankers, heavy plant equipment like bulldozers and harvesters, as well as the aircraft available to us," Mr Burns said who said the weather could lead to parts of the fire becoming active again.

"We are doing our utmost to ensure [a flare-up] doesn't happen again."

He said the focus now was on ensuring hot material did not escape the perimeter.

"We are systematically working around the perimeter of this fire, detecting and extinguishing all those hot spots or burning bits of material to ensure that they can't give rise to the fire escaping," Mr Burns said.

Mr Rankin said the perimeter was very long so the team was prioritising work at spots where the fire was most at risk of escaping.

"We are quite confident we will be able to continue to hold that control line," he said.

"What we are finding is that even on mild days with not too much wind, the fires are running quite quickly through the grass and into the forest."

High alert over hot weather forecast

Below average rainfalls and hotter temperatures over the past few years have created a large amount of fire fuel, including fallen leaves and dry grass.

"Our fire season really started in Gippsland in August and September, so that really goes to show the underlying dryness in the landscape," Mr Burns said.

Dry conditions means an active fire can quickly get out of control but in addition, one of the less visible aspects of the Rosedale fire is underground peat.

Peat is a highly combustible material, almost like coal, that can continue burning for months.

"The concern for us with this particular fire is that it will continue to burn underground, and potentially come to the surface at some point when the weather conditions become warmer," Mr Burns said.

But Mr Rankin emphasised that the peat in this fire was different to the peat that burned in south-west Victoria last year releasing a large amount of carbon monoxide.

"It's not an issue for the community and it's not an issue for our firefighters," he said.

"We are working with our team in Traralgon to come up with a management plan for the few bits of peat that we have inside the line."

Nervous time for local farmer

The fire means Longford hay and silage farmer Brad Cumming has had a stressful week.

"We obviously had the warning there was a fire south of Rosedale and we came down and did what we could before leaving the area," Mr Cumming said.

He returned on Saturday morning to find significant damage to his property.

"We lost all our front fences and our trees and windbreaks, a couple of internal fences and all the hay and silage," he said.

But he is grateful no lives have been lost.

Warning to community

While authorities appear confident the fire is mostly under control, they are warning the community to remain vigilant and continue to monitor emergency warnings.

Firefighters will continue working for weeks to come.

"At the point we are at [with] this fire, we've slowed the fire right down," Mr Burns said.

"It's not getting any bigger, but it's what I refer to as the hard dirty work or the grind."

Mr Cumming said he would not be taking any chances this weekend.

"Hopefully we've been burnt out enough now and there's no more to come," he said.

"But we'll still be on high alert with it definitely."
